title: View the contents of a
content: view-model Model View the contents of a About viewing models id1 about-viewing-models View attributes of an item id2 view-attributes-of-an-item View collections owned by an item id3 view-collections-owned-by-an-item Some gotchas id4 some-gotchas Useful snippets for viewing a model id5 useful-snippets-for-viewing-a-model contents local contents contents About viewing models id1 All CellML entities exist in a hierarchical structure as shown below. In some circumstances additional links are made between items (equivalent variables, for example), but on the whole it follows a basic tree structure. Within the structure each item has two parts: attributes name code initialValue code Variable code A set ofspecific to itself. Some of these attribute exist for many items (for example, theattribute), and others are specific to the item type (for example, theattribute on aitem). collections Variable code Component code A set ofwhich this - the parent item - curates. For example, the collection ofitems owned by a parent. - View attributes of an item id2 xyz code xyx() code Retrieving the value of an item’s attribute is simple, and follows the same general pattern throughout libCellML. Get the attributeusing the camelCase functionwithout arguments. For example: Variable code testVariable() code Reset code Note that the return value’s type will vary depending on the function. For example, aitem pointer is returned as theattribute value for aitem: view-attributes-of-an-item view\ attributes\ of\ an\ item View collections owned by an item id3 xyz code xyx(myIndex) code xyz(myName) code In order to access items within a collection use the same general format as above, but with an indicator (name or index) of the child item to be retrieved from the collection. In other words, get the child item of typeusing the camelCase functionor. The following example shows how all variables in a component can be listed. xyzCount() code Before accessing a collection item using an index, you can use thefunction to return the number of items in the collection. nb C++ panel-0-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-0-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-0-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-0-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-0-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-0-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-0-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-0-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element view-collections-owned-by-an-item view\ collections\ owned\ by\ an\ item Some gotchas id4 Units code Variable code Model code Component code The ownership of some collections can be a little counter-intuitive. One example is thatitems are referenced byitems, but are owned by the; this is so that units can be reused across more than one component. Another example involving encapsulation anditem ownership is shown below. Consider the following model: The raw CellML syntax stores each component individually as children of the model, and separately stores the encapsulation structure of the nested components. componentCount() code In libCellML, the encapsulation structure is embedded in the ownership of the components, so that one component can be a parent of another. This can be confusing if the simplefunction on a model is called naively, as shown below. title: Interact with generated code
content: solve-model Interact with generated code Interface with the generated code id1 interface-with-the-generated-code Set solution parameters id2 set-solution-parameters Initialise solution variables id3 initialise-solution-variables Compute the starting values of variables id4 compute-the-starting-values-of-variables Prepare files for output id5 prepare-files-for-output Perform the integration id6 perform-the-integration contents local contents contents Interface with the generated code id1 The generated code only represents the mathematical formulation of the model, so in order to find its solution it must be connected to an integration algorithm. This integration is not provided, but some basic functions to interact with the model are. Depending on whether you’re using C++ or Python, the generated code must either be compiled with your solver, or imported as a module. snippet-build-solver Build a solver using generated code header-left C++ snippet panel-0-0-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-0 0-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-0-0-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-1 0-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist This file should be saved as a CMakeLists.txt file for generation with CMake. tab-0-0-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-0-0-0 0-0 tabpanel 0 solveGeneratedModel.py xref download 720f0969a3d62e612fd4909324baa756/solveGeneratedModel.py solve_model True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.py download False Full context: tab-0-0-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-0-0-1 0-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element toggle snippet-build-solver snippet_build_solver interface-with-the-generated-code interface\ with\ the\ generated\ code Set solution parameters id2 In this very simple example we take the parameters for the integration step size and number of steps from command line arguments. snippet_get_parameters set-solution-parameters set\ solution\ parameters Initialise solution variables id3 As well as setting the number and size of the steps, the basic integration algorithm needs to store the state variables and their rates, as well as any other variables that are independent of the integration. create states array Note that since the number of state variables must be identical to the number of rates, the samefunction can be used to allocate storage for both of them. Following allocation, the states and constants can be initialised using the function provided. snippet-allocate-arrays Allocate solution arrays header-left C++ snippet panel-3-3-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-3-3-0 3-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-3-3-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-3-3-1 3-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist example_solveGeneratedModel.cpp xref download bcee499fcda27579ee11394c8ddb8c88/solveGeneratedModel.cpp solve_model True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.cpp download False Full context: tab-3-3-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-3-3-0 3-0 tabpanel 0 example_solveGeneratedModel.py xref download 720f0969a3d62e612fd4909324baa756/solveGeneratedModel.py solve_model True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.py download False Full context: tab-3-3-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-3-3-1 3-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element toggle snippet-allocate-arrays snippet_allocate_arrays initialise-solution-variables initialise\ solution\ variables Compute the starting values of variables id4 compute rates compute variables compute computed constants There are two kinds of variables stored in the generated code: those that require updating each step (the rates, but also any other variables which these depend upon); and those which do not affect the progress of the solution (everything else). The former kind is updated when thefunction is called, and the latter when thefunction is called. Constants clearly need be calculated only once, using thefunction. In this example we compute everything at the initial point so as to be able to output the starting values to the terminal. snippet-initialise-solver Initialise variables header-left C++ snippet panel-4-4-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-4-4-0 4-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-4-4-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-4-4-1 4-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist example_solveGeneratedModel.cpp xref download bcee499fcda27579ee11394c8ddb8c88/solveGeneratedModel.cpp solve_model True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.cpp download False Full context: tab-4-4-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-4-4-0 4-0 tabpanel 0 example_solveGeneratedModel.py xref download 720f0969a3d62e612fd4909324baa756/solveGeneratedModel.py solve_model True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.py download False Full context: tab-4-4-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-4-4-1 4-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element toggle snippet-initialise-solver snippet_initialise_solver compute-the-starting-values-of-variables compute\ the\ starting\ values\ of\ variables Prepare files for output id5 The solution is to be written directly to an output file during the iteration process, and this step is simply the preparation for that. The file is created and opened, and the columns labelled with information from the model. snippet-create-output Prepare for output header-left C++ snippet panel-5-5-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-5-5-0 5-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-5-5-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-5-5-1 5-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist example_solveGeneratedModel.cpp xref download bcee499fcda27579ee11394c8ddb8c88/solveGeneratedModel.cpp solve_model True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.cpp download False Full context: tab-5-5-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-5-5-0 5-0 tabpanel 0 example_solveGeneratedModel.py xref download 720f0969a3d62e612fd4909324baa756/solveGeneratedModel.py solve_model True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.py download False Full context: tab-5-5-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-5-5-1 5-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element toggle snippet-create-output snippet_create_output prepare-files-for-output prepare\ files\ for\ output Perform the integration id6 compute rates compute variables There are myriad stepping schemes for numerical integration, but here we use the very basic Euler method. At each step, new rates are calculated by calling thefunction. The states are then extrapolated from the rates using the Euler approximation step. In this example we are writing the output at every step, so we also need to update the variables too using thefunction, and everything is written to the output file. snippet-solve Perform the integration and output header-left C++ snippet panel-6-6-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-6-6-0 6-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-6-6-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-6-6-1 6-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist example_solveGeneratedModel.cpp xref download bcee499fcda27579ee11394c8ddb8c88/solveGeneratedModel.cpp solve_model True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.cpp download False Full context: tab-6-6-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-6-6-0 6-0 tabpanel 0 example_solveGeneratedModel.py xref download 720f0969a3d62e612fd4909324baa756/solveGeneratedModel.py solve_model True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.py download False Full context: tab-6-6-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-6-6-1 6-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element toggle snippet-solve snippet_solve perform-the-integration perform\ the\ integration interact-with-generated-code interact\ with\ generated\ code /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/howto-tested-docs/solve_model.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Resolve the imported items in a model
content: actions-resolve-imports Resolve the imported items in a model Units code Component code The import functionality foranditems is key to enabling the reuse and sharing of models. The import statements are basically a recipe for how these imported items can be combined to make the present model. While models which contain import dependencies are perfectly valid, they cannot be used to generate runnable code. The process of resolving the imports (telling libCellML where to look for these ingredients) and flattening the model (creating instances of the ingredients and removing the dependency) is necessary before code generation can happen. Importer code Theclass supports all functionality to do with imports, and contains its own logger which can be used to report anything that might have gone wrong. snippet-resolve-imports Resolve imports in a model header-left C++ snippet panel-0-0-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-0 0-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-0-0-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-1 0-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist example_simulationToolDev.cpp xref download 89c84d26a969eb1182bbdc7a0ffbaf8a/simulationToolDev.cpp resolve_imports True /resources/code/simulation_tool_dev/simulationToolDev.cpp download False Full context: tab-0-0-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-0-0-0 0-0 tabpanel 0 example_simulationToolDev.py xref download b302646fbd7722934aed90a32900e1e2/simulationToolDev.py resolve_imports True /resources/code/simulation_tool_dev/simulationToolDev.py download False Full context: tab-0-0-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-0-0-1 0-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element toggle snippet-resolve-imports snippet_resolve_imports resolve-the-imported-items-in-a-model resolve\ the\ imported\ items\ in\ a\ model /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/howto-tested-docs/resolve_imports.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Generate runnable code from a model
content: actions-generate-code Generate runnable code from a model Code generation is the process of representing the CellML model in another language format. At the time of writing, two profiles are available: C (default) and Python. There are four steps to code generation: Generator code Create aitem and select the profile language. (The default profile is C). Pass a model to the generator for processing. *.c code *.py code Retrieve the generated implementation code. This is the contents of thefile (if C is the profile) orif Python is selected. *.h code (optional) Retrieve the generated interface code. This is the contents of thefile, and is not required for the Python profile. arabic . snippet-generate-code Generate code from a model header-left C++ snippet panel-0-0-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-0 0-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-0-0-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-1 0-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist example_simulationToolDev.cpp xref download 89c84d26a969eb1182bbdc7a0ffbaf8a/simulationToolDev.cpp generate_code True /resources/code/simulation_tool_dev/simulationToolDev.cpp download False Full context: tab-0-0-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-0-0-0 0-0 tabpanel 0 example_simulationToolDev.py xref download b302646fbd7722934aed90a32900e1e2/simulationToolDev.py generate_code True /resources/code/simulation_tool_dev/simulationToolDev.py download False Full context: tab-0-0-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-0-0-1 0-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element toggle snippet-generate-code snippet_generate_code generate-runnable-code-from-a-model generate\ runnable\ code\ from\ a\ model /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/howto-tested-docs/generate_code.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Edit items in a model
content: edit-model Edit items in a model All CellML entities exist in an hierarchical structure as shown below. In some circumstances additional links are made between items (equivalent variables, for example), but on the whole it follows a basic tree structure. Within the structure each item has two parts: attributes name code initialValue code Variable code A set ofspecific to itself. Some of these attribute exist for many items (for example, theattribute), and others are specific to the item type (for example, theattribute on aitem). collections Variable code Component code A set ofwhich this - the parent item - curates. For example, the collection ofitems owned by a parent. - Editing attributes id1 editing-attributes Editing collections id2 editing-collections Editing variable equivalences id3 editing-variable-equivalences Editing an encapsulation hierarchy id4 editing-an-encapsulation-hierarchy contents local contents contents Editing attributes id1 xyz code setXyz code For any item type, each attributemay be edited using the generalfunction, whose arguments vary depending on the attribute. Note that this is distinct from editing collections of items, which is discussed below. Some example snippets are shown below: TODO snippet-edit-mathml Edit MathML in a component header-left C++ panel-0-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-0-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-0-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-0-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-0-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-0-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-0-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-0-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element math() code MathML is stored as a single string within a component. Retrieving it is simple enough using thefunction, but any manipulation (change units used, changing variable names, adding additional relationships, etc) are a little more complicated. preserve TODO: Need more examples of useful mathml manipulation. Variable names? Need to remove whitespace first? toggle snippet-edit-mathml snippet_edit_mathml editing-attributes editing\ attributes Editing collections id2 addXyz code removeXyz code takeXyz code replaceXyz code Understanding collections False /documentation/v0.6.3/aside/understanding_collections General families of functions are available for editing collections, but take the form ofand,and, as explained in. Some example snippets are shown below: snippet-add-thing snippet-remove-thing snippet-take-thing snippet-replace-thing Add a thing to a collection header-left C++ panel-1-1-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-0 1-0 tab 0 Python panel-1-1-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-1 1-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-1-1-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-1-1-0 1-0 tabpanel 0 tab-1-1-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-1-1-1 1-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element moves When you add an item to a collection, you also set its parent. Effectively, adding an item which is already a member of one collection to another collection actuallyit from the first to the second. This means that: the item’s parent will be the second collection parent; the first collection will not contain the item any more; and the second collection will contain the item. - toggle snippet-add-thing snippet_add_thing Remove a thing from a collection header-left C++ panel-2-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-2-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-2-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-2-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-2-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-2-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-2-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-2-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element This example demonstrates the addition and removal of items from a collection. Note that while removal of items from a collection can be done by pointer symbol, by name, and by index, adding them is only possible via pointer. toggle snippet-remove-thing snippet_remove_thing Take a thing from a collection header-left toggle snippet-take-thing snippet_take_thing Replace a thing within a collection header-left toggle snippet-replace-thing snippet_replace_thing editing-collections editing\ collections Editing variable equivalences id3 In the situation of equivalent variable collections there is no clear “ownership” of the equivalence as an attribute of any one variable, and neither is there a central parent item with curation ability over the set of variables. A different approach is required. addEquivalence code removeEquivalence code addEquivalence code Adding and removing variable equivalence is accomplished using theandfunctions as shown below. These functions take arguments of the variable pointers to connect or dissociate, and return a boolean value indicating whether the operation was successful. The success of thefunction depends on: valid Creating aconnection also depends on the two variables having compatible units, appropriate interface types, and being in components which are accessible to one another (parent-child or sibling relationship). removeEquivalence code The success of thefunction depends on: removeEquivalence code addEquivalence code Note that thefunction will only remove an equivalence which was previously set using thefunction; it does not remove any indirect connections via third-party variables between the two. removeAllEquivalences code An additionalfunction will completely remove the variable from any connected set. API Variable False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Variable Please see thepage for details of these functions. fruit code apple code pear code peach code vegetable code tomato code celery code spinach code produce code fruit code vegetable code peach code spinach code There are some gotchas to be explained. A variable can belong to only one set of equivalent variables; by having more than one equivalent variable, the variable itself merges the two sets of variables into one. Consider this example. Variableis equivalent to variables,, and. Another variableis equivalent to variables,, and. At this time, there are two sets of equivalent variables: all of the fruit are equivalent to one another, and all of the vegetables are equivalent to one another. Adding a variablewith an equivalence toand toeffectively merges the two sets, so that now the variableis equivalent to. the variable pointers being non-null; the two variables having parent components; there being no previously existing connection between the two variables already. - the variable pointer arguments being non-null; and there being an existing connection between the two variables. - C++ panel-3-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-3-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-3-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-3-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-3-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-3-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-3-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-3-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element editing-variable-equivalences editing\ variable\ equivalences Editing an encapsulation hierarchy id4 Components may be added to a model or another component to create an encapsulation hierarchy, but there are a few things to watch out for in this situation. Components must belong to only one parent, so when adding a component from one location in the encapsulation to another, it is removed from the original parent. title: Check a model
content: check-model Check a model Validator code Analyser code Two checker classes are provided in libCellML; theand theclasses. These can be used to check the syntax and structure of your model is correct (validating), and to check that its mathematical representation is solvable (analysing). validate-model Validate a model Validator code Theis the equivalent of a spelling checker: it can check that each item in a model has all of the information it needs, but it can’t check whether it means what you intend it to. Thus even if a model is valid, it could still be the equivalent of correctly-spelled nonsense. Validator code ERROR code CellML normative specification False https://cellml-specification.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ Once a model has been passed to ainstance, the validator’s internal logger will contain a list of any of the issues which have been encountered during the checking process. A model can be said to be valid - that is, conforming to the- if the validator’s logger contains no issues with a level of. Get Issues std std-ref True get-issues For more information on how to use any of the classes which record issues, please see thesection below. snippet-validate-model get-issues Validate a model against the CellML specification header-left C++ snippet panel-0-0-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-0 0-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-0-0-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-1 0-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist example_simulationToolDev.cpp xref download 89c84d26a969eb1182bbdc7a0ffbaf8a/simulationToolDev.cpp check_model True /resources/code/simulation_tool_dev/simulationToolDev.cpp download False Full context: tab-0-0-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-0-0-0 0-0 tabpanel 0 example_simulationToolDev.py xref download b302646fbd7722934aed90a32900e1e2/simulationToolDev.py check_model True /resources/code/simulation_tool_dev/simulationToolDev.py download False Full context: tab-0-0-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-0-0-1 0-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element toggle snippet-validate-model snippet_validate_model validate-a-model validate-model validate\ a\ model validate_model Retrieve Issue items Logger code Selected libCellML classes contain awhose job it is to curate any issues encountered within the class, and return them to the user when asked. issueCount()-1 code ERROR code WARNING code HINT code MESSAGE code Individual issues can be retrieved from the parent class by their index, an integer between 0 and. Each issue contains a severity level indicator, one of four levels (,,, or): Issues can also be retrieved from subgroups based on their severity, as shown in the examples below. Issue code Eachalso contains the following attributes: The classes are: Parser code theclass; Validator code theclass; Printer code theclass; Analyser code theclass; Importer code theclass; and Generator code theclass. - shortlist ERROR code level indicates issues that must be resolved before the model is valid and runnable; WARNING code level indicates a non-fatal issue, but one that may cause hidden or unintended consequences; HINT code level indicates a commonly encountered valid-but-nonsense situation; and MESSAGE code level is for your information but does not require action. - shortlist C++ panel-1-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-1-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-1-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-1-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-1-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-1-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-1-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-1-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element COMPONENT code , CONNECTION code , ENCAPSULATION code , IMPORT code , MAP_VARIABLES code , MATHML code , MODEL code , RESET code , RESET_VALUE code , TEST_VALUE code , UNDEFINED code , UNIT code , UNITS code , VARIABLE code , and XML code . - shortlist C++ panel-2-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-2-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-2-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-2-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-2-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-2-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-2-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-2-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element A description: a brief statement about the problem and how it might be fixed; This includes checking things like that all variables requiring initial values have them, that equations do not conflict with one another, and that any variables used in equations are actually defined in the model. title: Annotate a model
content: annotate-model Annotate a model 1.2.5 XML ID attributes False https://cellml-specification.readthedocs.io/en/latest/specA2.html?issue=XML libCellML does not provide annotation functionality directly, but it can help with some of the things that you might need to know in order to implement your own. Each annotation is attached to a unique ID locator which can be retrieved and edited, or created automatically if you haven’t already set them yourself. Since CellML is a subset of XML, any item may have an ID attribute, including operations within the MathML blocks, CellML entities, and CellML non-entity items (connections, encapsulations etc). These ID attributes themselves must follow the specification rules: please seefor details. id code At present, items within MathML blocks which haveattributes are not retrieved or edited by the annotation class. Any editing or manipulation must be done external to libCellML. nb Annotation tools for entity items id1 annotation-tools-for-entity-items Annotation tools for other item types id2 annotation-tools-for-other-item-types Connections and variable equivalence id3 connections-and-variable-equivalence Encapsulation and component references id4 encapsulation-and-component-references Unit item children; reset_value, test_value item children id5 unit-item-children-reset-value-test-value-item-children Type Annotatorand returned types id6 annotator-type-and-returned-types Useful snippets for annotation id7 useful-snippets-for-annotation contents local contents contents Annotation tools for entity items id1 Entity item types are: id code id() code setId() code Theattribute for each of these entity types can be retrieved using thefunction for the object, or set through itsfunction. title: Testing libCellML
content: testing Testing libCellML Every pull request against the libCellML prime repository is tested as a matter of course, but there might be times when you’d like to test your own code without making a pull request. There are two ways you can do this. Using the Buildbot site Buildbot False https://buildbot.net/ ForceScheduler False http://docs.buildbot.net/latest/developer/cls-forcesched.html Buildbot False https://buildbot.net/ d.nickerson@auckland.ac.nz mailto:d.nickerson@auckland.ac.nz Buildbot False https://buildbot.net/ htpasswd False https://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/programs/htpasswd.html has the capacity to build a libCellML compliant repository through the use of a. To make use of this facility, you will need to authenticate with thesystem. Access granted on request to David Nickerson. Thesystem uses MD5 encrypted passwords as created by. With your request to David include the output of this command: http://www.htaccesstools.com/htpasswd-generator/ http://www.htaccesstools.com/htpasswd-generator/ libCellML Buildbot False https://autotest.bioeng.auckland.ac.nz/buildbot/libcellml/#/builders The websitecan be used if you do not have access to the htpasswd application. When your request has been dealt with, you will be able to login toand submit code for testing. using-the-buildbot-site using\ the\ buildbot\ site Manually on your local computer build/test code When your libCellML has built successfully, and with tests included, executables for the tests will be located in thedirectory where your library has been built. Unit tests make test code Run all of the unit tests using. tests/ code test_classname code classname code tests/test_classname code Individual C++ unit tests may be run by locating the test executable within the, directory. Unit tests for a given class are named, whereis the lowercase name of the class to test. These files are executable, so can be run from the command line. tests/bindings/python/ code python test_classname.py code classname code To run individual Python tests, navigate first into thedirectory. The test files can then be run individually as needed using, whereis the lowercase name of the class to test. - Coverage tests TODO make llvm_coverage code Coverage tests make sure that each line of code is covered by one or more unit tests. - A summary of coverage of the C++ code is accessible through, which result in statistics of line coverage. - For detailed information regarding specific lines in each file that need test coverage, use the command. Formatting tests TODO make test_clang_format code Check that the code is correctly formatted using the, if you have CLang installed.Check what other OS use? Memory tests TODO - manually-on-your-local-computer manually\ on\ your\ local\ computer testing-libcellml testing testing\ libcellml testing /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/src/docs/testing.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Development setup
content: setup Development setup working copy This section describes how someone wanting to contribute to the libCellML project should set up theirfor developing libCellML. Overview Github False https://github.com/ Git False https://git-scm.com/ The libCellML codebase is hosted onand thereforeis used to track changes. Before you begin, you will need to have a few pre-requisites satisfied: If Python bindings are required, the following packages are also needed: Github False https://github.com/ andre user account (for the rest of this document we will call our user); Git False https://git-scm.com/ for tracking changes in code; CMake False https://cmake.org/ to configure the build files; Toolchain for building the library (dependent on the operating system); libxml2 False http://xmlsoft.org/ , an external library used to parse XML; zlib False https://www.zlib.net/ , an external library used for compression; and Doxygen False http://www.doxygen.nl/ to generate documentation. arabic . shortlist Python False https://www.python.org/ Version 3.5.2 or later is needed for Sphinx (see below) SWIG False http://swig.org to generate the bindings for Python Sphinx False http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/ to generate documentation for Python bindings loweralpha . shortlist overview overview Pre-requisite acquisition In this section, we cover the retrieval and installation of pre-requisites. setup-git Git Github False https://github.com/ Github sign-up page False https://github.com//join Creating auser account is straightforward and can be done on the. Installing a Git client is particular to each operating system and some pointers are offered below: Windows Git for windows Git for windows http://gitforwindows.org/ GitHub Desktop GitHub Desktop https://desktop.github.com/ GitKracken GitKracken https://www.gitkraken.com/ Git SCM Git SCM https://git-scm.com/ Git is available from a variety of vendors. We commonly use, but other popular implementations are: --- Linux sudo apt-get install git code Git can be installed using the package manager with the command. macOS Git is pre-installed and available from the command line. - setup-cmake git setup-git git setup_git CMake CMake False https://cmake.org/ is the cross-platform family of tools designed to build, test and package software. CMake is used to control the software compilation process using simple platform and compiler independent configuration files, and to generate native makefiles and workspaces that can be used in the compiler environment of your choice. Note that CMake version 3.2 or later is required to configure libCellML. Again, installation of CMake is particular to each operating system. Windows installation binaries False https://cmake.org//download/ CMake provides. Choose the binary appropriate for your operating system and follow the installation instructions. Linux sudo apt-get install cmake code CMake can be installed using the package manager with the command. macOS installation binaries False https://cmake.org//download/ CMake provides. Choose the binary appropriate for your operating system and follow the installation instructions. - setup-toolchain cmake setup-cmake cmake setup_cmake Toolchain The toolchain specifies the compiler that we will use to build libCellML. Toolchains are highly dependent on the operating system. When we test libCellML, we currently use: We recommend using these compilers on these systems, but feel free to use a different toolchain. The following sub-sections provide guidance on how to install the recommended toolchain on the major operating systems that libCellML supports. Windows Microsoft Visual Studio False https://visualstudio.microsoft.com ; Linux GCC False https://gcc.gnu.org/ ; and macOS Clang False https://clang.llvm.org/ . - Windows the MSVS download page False https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/downloads/ Community Visual Studio is available to download from. We currently test with Visual Studio 2015 (version 14), but later versions are known to work. Theedition is more than sufficient for the needs of libCellML. To minimise the size of the installation, you may install only the C++ compiler. This component (and its requirements) is sufficient for building libCellML. Linux TODO macOS TODO - setup-zlib toolchain setup-toolchain toolchain setup_toolchain zlib zlib False https://www.zlib.net/ is a common compression library. It is important to use a 64-bit version of the library as the 32-bit is not compatible with libCellML. Windows OpenCMISS zlib releases page False https://github.com/OpenCMISS-Dependencies/zlib/releases zlib False https://www.zlib.net/ On Windows, it is easiest to install using the packaged version available from theon GitHub. You are welcome to build your own version if you would rather, but please make sure it is a 64-bit implementation. To buildfrom source refer to the next sub-section. Linux sudo apt install zlib1g-dev code For Debian-based systems, zlib can be installed using. macOS zlib is already installed on macOS, so no further action is required on that platform. - Building from source To create a zlib library suitable for libCellML, we need to download, configure, build, and install it. https://github.com/OpenCMISS-Dependencies/zlib https://github.com/OpenCMISS-Dependencies/zlib To download zlib, clone the repository: Create a build directory and change into it: Create the zlib library build instructions using CMake: <ZLIB_INSTALL_DIR> code Whereis to be replaced by a path on your computer. Something like: Andre code if your username was. We can now build the library with the command: The last thing we do is to install the library with the command: setup-libxml2 building\ from\ source building-from-source zlib setup-zlib zlib setup_zlib libxml2 libxml2 False http://xmlsoft.org/ is a parser and toolkit for manipulating XML files and text. It is important to use a 64-bit version of the library as the 32-bit is not compatible with libCellML. Windows OpenCMISS libxml2 releases page False https://github.com/OpenCMISS-Dependencies/libxml2/releases libxml2 False http://xmlsoft.org/ On Windows, it is easiest to install using the packaged version available from theon GitHub. You are welcome to build your own version if you would rather, but please make sure it is a 64-bit implementation. To buildfrom source refer to the next sub-section. Linux sudo apt install libxml2-dev code For Debian-based systems, libxml2 can be installed using. macOS libxml2 is already installed on macOS, so no further action is required on that platform. - Building from source To create a libxml2 library suitable for libCellML, we need to download, configure, build, and install it. libxml2 can be configured to use zlib, so build and install that first before following these instructions. https://github.com/OpenCMISS-Dependencies/libxml2 https://github.com/OpenCMISS-Dependencies/libxml2 To download libxml2, clone the repository: Create a build directory and change into it: Create the libxml2 library build instructions using CMake: <ZLIB_INSTALL_DIR> code <LIBXML2_INSTALL_DIR> code <LIBXML2_INSTALL_DIR> code Whereis to be replaced by the path on your computer where zlib is installed.also needs to be replaced by a path on your computer. Using the same directory that the zlib library is installed to is a good idea. Following this advice we would setto: <ZLIB_INSTALL_DIR> code andwould be given the same value. We can now build the library with the command: The last thing we do is to install the library with the command: setup-doxygen building\ from\ source id1 libxml2 setup-libxml2 libxml2 setup_libxml2 Doxygen Doxygen False http://www.doxygen.nl/ is software which assembles documentation files directly from annotated source code, including the generation of inheritance and dependency tree diagrams for classes. In order for libCellML to build its documentation you will need to have Doxygen and its dependencies installed. Note that this does not affect your use of the libCellML library itself. Windows download page of the Doxygen website False http://www.doxygen.nl//download.html#srcbin download Graphviz False http://graphviz.org/download/ Binary distributions are available from the. You may also need to download and install the Graphviz package in order to generate the class hierarchy diagrams. You canfrom their website. Linux download page of the Doxygen website False http://www.doxygen.nl//download.html#srcbin Binary distributions are available from the. macOS download page of the Doxygen website False http://www.doxygen.nl//download.html#srcbin Binary distributions are available from the. - setup-python doxygen setup-doxygen doxygen setup_doxygen Python (optional) Python False https://www.python.org/ Building LibCellML std std-ref True configure_and_build#configure-and-build is an open-source language which is syntactically easier to read than other higher-level languages. It is commonly used as a scripting language for experimentation, and is included here to allow libCellML to be accessed from Python-based programs. Note that creation of Python bindings is optional, and can be enabled/disabled at configuration time - there will be instructions for this on thepage. Windows the Python download page False https://www.python.org//downloads/windows/ Python binaries for Windows can be found on, or you can build your own from source files if you prefer. Linux Python download page False https://www.python.org//downloads/source/ Linux natively includes Python, but depending on the age of your machine and system installation, you may like to upgrade to a more recent version from the. macOS later version from the Python site False https://www.python.org/downloads/mac-osx/ Python is already installed, though depending on the age of your machine you may like to upgrade it to a. - setup-swig python-optional setup-python python\ (optional) setup_python SWIG for Python bindings (optional) SWIG False http://swig.org Python False https://www.python.org/ is a tool which acts as a translator between code written in C++ and other languages, including. Here SWIG is used to generate the optional Python bindings for libCellML. The current version (0.9) of libCellML uses SWIG 4.0.0. Windows Swigwin download page False https://sourceforge.net/projects/swig/files/swigwin/ SWIG for Windows is available from the. Linux Both Python and SWIG are already included, so no further action is needed. macOS downloads for Unix/Linux sources False http://swig.org/download.html SWIG for macOS can be accessed using theand building them locally according to the instructions provided on that page. - setup-sphinx swig-for-python-bindings-optional setup-swig swig\ for\ python\ bindings\ (optional) setup_swig Sphinx for Python documentation (optional) Sphinx False http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/ Installation page False http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master//usage/installation.html import error False https://github.com/rtfd/readthedocs.org/issues/3812 is an additional documentation tool used here to assemble documentation of the Python bindings. Instructions for all operating systems can be found on their. The current version (2.0.1) needs Python version 3.5.2 or later (note that Python subversions 3.5.0 and 3.5.1 will still raise andespite being reported fixed since version Sphinx 1.7.2). setup-codebase sphinx-for-python-documentation-optional setup-sphinx sphinx\ for\ python\ documentation\ (optional) setup_sphinx pre-requisite-acquisition pre-requisite\ acquisition Setting up the codebase GitHub Desktop False https://desktop.github.com/ The remainder of this document assumes that the above pre-requisites have been met, and covers setup from the command line. If you are using a GUI likethen you will need to adjust the commands accordingly. prime libCellML repository xref std std-term True glossary#term-prime-libCellML-repository Fig. 22 std std-numref True repository-setup Fig. %s The goal here is to get a working copy of source code, tests, and documentation onto your computer so that you can begin development. To make this happen, you will need to fork the, make a clone onto your computer, and set up the Git remotes. In, you can see a pictorial representation of what we are aiming to achieve. The four steps to getting set up are detailed below. title: Roadmap
content: libcellmlroadmap Roadmap id2 Updated: 09 March 2021. Each milestone may consist of several ‘releases’ and future requirements may impact the design and implementation of earlier releases of libCellML. Major changes in the API will be accepted up to the release of libCellML version 1.0.0. Contents Roadmap id2 roadmap High level objectives id3 high-level-objectives Environment id4 environment Requirements id5 requirements Milestone 1: Python bindings, validation, code generation, and documentation id6 milestone-1-python-bindings-validation-code-generation-and-documentation Milestone 2: units, JavaScript, and resets id7 milestone-2-units-javascript-and-resets Milestone 3: DAE models id8 milestone-3-dae-models Milestone 4: advanced capabilities id9 milestone-4-advanced-capabilities contents contents contents High level objectives id3 libCellML is focused on CellML 2.0 and beyond. The implementation of libCellML should be driven by the requirements for supporting CellML 2.0 and beyond. libCellML should be designed to support the CellML specification with the flexibility for extra restrictions, constraints, or additions coming from future proposals for changing the specification. * libCellML should be able to parse models in CellML 2.0 and newer versions of the specification. libCellML will only serialise models to the current version of the specification. * high-level-objectives high\ level\ objectives Environment id4 This section will specify the environment for the development of libCellML. GitHub GitHub https://github.com/ CellML organisation CellML organisation https://github.com/cellml github github https://github.com/ cellml-organisation cellml\ organisation https://github.com/cellml to host the primary libCellML source repository and issue tracker under the(current and former editorial board members). SWIG SWIG http://www.swig.org/ emscripten emscripten https://emscripten.org/ swig swig http://www.swig.org/ emscripten emscripten https://emscripten.org/ Development language: primary implementation in C++ withPython bindings andbased WebAssembly for JavaScript bindings. CMake CMake http://www.cmake.org/ cmake cmake http://www.cmake.org/ Build:for generating cross-platform build rules. Buildbot Buildbot http://buildbot.net/ buildbot buildbot http://buildbot.net/ Test: usingon our own servers to run continuous integration testing. gtest gtest https://github.com/google/googletest/ gtest gtest https://github.com/google/googletest/ Test: unit testing to use. reStructuredText reStructuredText http://docutils.sourceforge.net/docs/ref/rst/restructuredtext.html restructuredtext restructuredtext http://docutils.sourceforge.net/docs/ref/rst/restructuredtext.html Documentation: written in. Doxygen Doxygen http://www.doxygen.org/ doxygen doxygen http://www.doxygen.org/ Documentation: API and source code examples will be documented using C++-stylecomments. libcellml.org libcellml.org https://libcellml.org Website:. website source website source https://github.com/libcellml/website-src website-source website\ source https://github.com/libcellml/website-src Website: content pulled from libCellML documentation, tutorials, and. Deploy: use Github actions to build artifacts for deployment. * Requirements id5 libcellml.org libcellml.org https://libcellml.org/ Documentation: made available on. Documentation: is amenable for inclusion in external documentation efforts Development: Agile, test driven development where: Functionality is more important than API stability in early releases. Release early and often. * pull request pull request https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests GitHub GitHub https://github.com/ pull-request pull\ request https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests github id1 https://github.com/ Development: code review prior to acceptance into the primary repository using thefeature on. Development: objectives are added and broken down into incremental tasks. Development: a single task should be no more than two weeks. * We should avoid using non-standard system libraries unless there is a compelling reason. Once features are available, the API can be fine tuned in consultation with the CellML community. requirements requirements environment environment Milestone 1: Python bindings, validation, code generation, and documentation id6 Python bindings. Wrap the libCellML API using SWIG to be able to generate Python bindings for the library. Package the bindings so they can be easily installed across Windows, Linux, and macOS. arabic . Load a CellML 2.0 model and validate it. reset code Validate models against the rules defined in the current draft of the CellML 2.0 specification (currently an active document, outstanding issues regarding the newconstruct are likely to require updates to the validation implementation). arabic . Code generation. Focus on non-DAE models. Generate code for any simulatable non-DAE CellML model in PMR (i.e., translated from CellML 1.0/1.1). Guide the code generated for a given model (e.g., a variable to be controlled from an external data source, SED-ML defined changes, etc.). arabic . Documentation available. API. Tutorials/documented code examples. Integrating libCellML into common IDEs (Visual Studio, Qt Creator, and PyCharm). Provide documentation on the installation and use of the Python bindings across Windows, Linux, and macOS. arabic . arabic . milestone-1-python-bindings-validation-code-generation-and-documentation milestone\ 1:\ python\ bindings,\ validation,\ code\ generation,\ and\ documentation Milestone 2: units, JavaScript, and resets id7 Units. Checking units within mathematical expressions. Debugging assistance for model authors regarding units. arabic . JavaScript. Use Emscripten to create a JavaScript API for libCellML. Provide a suitable packaged version of the JavaScript API for integration in common JavaScript environments (e.g., Node, Browser). Document the installation and use of the JavaScript API. arabic . Resets. Extend libCellML implementation to fully support resets. arabic . arabic . milestone-2-units-javascript-and-resets milestone\ 2:\ units,\ javascript,\ and\ resets Milestone 3: DAE models id8 DAE models. Code generation support for models with DAEs. arabic . arabic . milestone-3-dae-models milestone\ 3:\ dae\ models Milestone 4: advanced capabilities id9 High-order model manipulation (recall the discussion with Andrew McCulloch at the 8th CellML workshop). Again, it is outside the scope of libCellML, but helping tool developers provide these kinds of services is very important. arabic . arabic . milestone-4-advanced-capabilities milestone\ 4:\ advanced\ capabilities roadmap libcellmlroadmap roadmap libcellmlroadmap /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/src/docs/roadmap.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Review process
content: review-process Review process This chapter details the responsibilities of the repository owners, and will help contributors to understand how their code contributions will be assessed and reviewed. Check for the green tick libCellML Buildbot False https://autotest.bioeng.auckland.ac.nz/buildbot/libcellml/#/builders Before accepting a tranche of work into the libCellML prime repository check that thehas tested and passed the code. The status of the code is shown in the last commit of a pushed group of commits in the pull request. The last commit will have a red cross for a failed build or a green tick for a passed build. Obviously, make sure that the last commit has a green tick before merging. The “Details” link at the bottom of the pull request web page will take you to the build records of the library. This page shows the results of the unit tests for each target operating system, the results of the coverage test, the results of the memory check test, and the results of the documentation build. gcovr False https://gcovr.com/ Coverage Statistics std std-ref True coverage_statistics#coverage-statistics The coverage statistics for the library (generated from) can be reached through thepage. check-for-the-green-tick check\ for\ the\ green\ tick Read the documentation TODO Update needed now that documentation is integrated into libcellml.org. The documentation for the project is built as part of the testing process. The Documentation Builder link (entry 2 in step 5) will take you to the build for the documentation. On this page, you can see the steps taken to build the documentation. In the last step of the build (step 7), there is a link ‘dox’ (entry 2) that will take you to the built documentation. Doxygen False http://www.doxygen.nl/ API Documentation False /documentation/latest/api/classlibcellml_1_1 The documentation should be reviewed in its final format particularly those parts of the documentation that (should) have changed due to the current pull request. The API documentation (generated by) can be reached from thepages. Note that it may be some time before changes to the documentation are seen on that site, as there is currently not a live connection between the repository and the API documentation on this website. read-the-documentation read\ the\ documentation Resolving comments All comments on the pull request and associated issue should be responded to and satisfied. It’s useful if contributors include the Git commit number (a six or seven digit hexadecimal code) in which any requested code changes are made in their reply to reviewer comments. It is the reviewers’ responsibility to check that appropriate changes have been made before merging the pull request. resolving-comments resolving\ comments Coding standards Google C++ Style Guide False https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html Coding Standards std std-ref True coding_standards#coding-standards Currently, there is no fully-defined libCellML coding standards set, but thecan be considered a baseline for the standard of code that is expected for libCellML. See thedocument for deviations from this guideline. coding-standards coding\ standards Merging a pull request release_staging_<version number> Caution: before merging a pull request make sure that a release is not currently in progress. If a release is in progress, the prime repository will have a branch called(where <version number> is a semantic version number). When merging a pull request, the reviewer should add a comment so that the corresponding issue is closed. This can be done by adding a directive to the merge commit, like so: the Github article for a list of all directives False https://help.github.com/articles/closing-issues-via-commit-messages/ where the numeral corresponds to the issue that needs to be closed. You can use other closing directives that will achieve the same outcome, please seethat will work on Github. merging-a-pull-request merging\ a\ pull\ request review-process id1 review\ process review_process /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/src/docs/review_process.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Release process for
content: release-process libCellML Release process for libCellML cellml/libcellml cellml/libcellml https://github.com/cellml/libcellml The target audience of this document are the developers of, who have write authority to therepository. Releases are made using builders from the Buildbot Continuous Integration (CI). There are four steps in making a release. Each section has further details on what actions are required for a particular step. Each step must be done in order from step 1 through to step 4. admin For all the steps in creating a release, you must be logged in to the Buildbot CI and be in thegroup. Step 1 - Setting the version number Step 1 - Setting the version number step-1-setting-the-version-number Step 2 - Preparing the release Step 2 - Preparing the release step-2-preparing-the-release Step 3 - Creating the release Step 3 - Creating the release step-3-creating-the-release Step 4 - Finalising the Release Step 4 - Finalising the Release step-4-finalising-the-release arabic . version_change release_staging_<version number> Merging in pull requests when a release is under way is not recommended and more importantly has not been tested. To determine if a release is under way check the repository for the presence of a branch namedor. Step 1 - Setting the version number Set Version Builder Set Version Builder Fig. 11 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-set-version-builder Fig. %s The version number for the project can be set using the(). Thesets the version that is entered into the interface, it does not increment the version. The version that you set in the interface will be applied as is to the codebase. Semantic versioning Semantic versioning https://semver.org/ semantic-versioning semantic\ versioning https://semver.org/ libCellML uses semantic versioning as a versioning system, seefor further information. As such, each part of the version number carries a specific meaning and when setting a version number you need to make sure you are following semantic versioning rules. There are no checks to determine if semantic versioning is being followed. The version number is split into two parts: the core version, made up of the major, minor, and patch version identifiers; and the developer version. An official release is created by leaving the developer version input empty. The main difference between an official release and a developer release is the assets built by the developer release process are not uploaded or published to public registries or attached to an associated GitHub release. Start Build version_change main vesion_change version_change Fig. 12 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-set-version-builder-interface Fig. %s cellml/libcellml cellml/libcellml https://github.com/cellml/libcellml When thebutton is pressed () Buildbot will create an internal pull request on theGitHub repository. The pull request will be made from thebranch to thebranch. The creation of the pull request will trigger a CI build, wait for the CI to finish its checks before merging the pull request. If, for some reason, the CI checks fail changes may be required. Changes can be made directly to thebranch but quite likely any such changes will need to be propagated to the CI for a permanent fix. How changes are propagated to the CI is outside the scope of this document. When merging the pull request thebranch will be automatically deleted. main When the version number has been set in thebranch the preparation of the release can start. Buildbot set version builder. {'*': 'images/release_process/set_version_builder.png'} images/release_process/set_version_builder.png Set Version Builder on Buildbot. center libcellml-release-process-set-version-builder libcellml_release_process_set_version_builder Buildbot set version builder interface. {'*': 'images/release_process/set_version_builder_interface.png'} images/release_process/set_version_builder_interface.png Fig. 12 Set Version Builder interface. center libcellml-release-process-set-version-builder-interface libcellml_release_process_set_version_builder_interface version_change The merging of apull request created by the CI system is exempt from the ‘two reviews’ required rule. step-1-setting-the-version-number step\ 1\ -\ setting\ the\ version\ number Step 2 - Preparing the release Prepare Release Builder Prepare Release Builder release_staging_<version number> Fig. 13 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-prepare-release Fig. %s A release is prepared using the(). Thewill create a new branch named(where <version number> is an actual semantic version number set in the first step) and generate a changelog. The changelog for a release is generated from information found in merged pull requests between the current release under preparation and the previous release. Prepare Release Builder Fig. 14 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-prepare-release-builder-interface Fig. %s There are no options for the, there is only one place you can prepare a release from, there is only one place a release is going to be created. The only thing you can do is start a build, (). Prepare Release Builder Thewill kick off a round of unit tests as part of the preparation process. release_staging_<version number> main When the release has been prepared thebranch will have been created and a changelog and table of contents entries for the changelog will have been created. Manual changes to the generated changelog can be made at this point in the release process. The changes made for the new changelog should be the only changes from the currentbranch. Buildbot prepare release builder interface. {'*': 'images/release_process/prepare_release_builder.png'} images/release_process/prepare_release_builder.png Prepare Release Builder on Buildbot. center libcellml-release-process-prepare-release libcellml_release_process_prepare_release Buildbot prepare release interface. {'*': 'images/release_process/prepare_release_builder_interface.png'} images/release_process/prepare_release_builder_interface.png Fig. 14 Prepare Release Builder interface. center libcellml-release-process-prepare-release-builder-interface libcellml_release_process_prepare_release_builder_interface The changelog creation is unlikely to be accurate when creating a bug fix/hot fix release on a previously released official version. At this time, that means some manual editing of the changelog will need to happen when creating a bug fix/hot fix release. step-2-preparing-the-release step\ 2\ -\ preparing\ the\ release Step 3 - Creating the release Create Release Builder Fig. 15 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-create-release Fig. %s A release is created using the(). release_staging_<version number> Create Release Builder Start Build cellml/libcellml cellml/libcellml https://github.com/cellml/libcellml Fig. 16 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-create-release-builder-interface Fig. %s A release can only be created from abranch. Theinterface interrogatesfor potential release branches. Select the release preparation branch (there should only ever be one), to create the release from, and start the build with thebutton,. Create Release Builder release_staging_<version number> release release Thecreates a release on GitHub and adds tags to identify where the release was created from. The current status for thebranch will be applied to thebranch. The taggedbranch is where the GitHub release will be created from. When the release is created GitHub actions will take over to build all the assets. The assets here are the binaries: installers and archives from Windows, macOS, and Ubuntu; Python wheels; and, the Javascript package. Buildbot create release builder interface. {'*': 'images/release_process/create_release_builder.png'} images/release_process/create_release_builder.png Create Release Builder on Buildbot. center libcellml-release-process-create-release libcellml_release_process_create_release Buildbot create release interface. {'*': 'images/release_process/create_release_builder_interface.png'} images/release_process/create_release_builder_interface.png Fig. 16 Create Release Builder interface showing the branch a release can be created from. center libcellml-release-process-create-release-builder-interface libcellml_release_process_create_release_builder_interface Do not Finalise Release Builder start theuntil the deploy libCellML GitHub action has finished. The GitHub action for deploying libCellML is currently taking between 11 and 15 minutes to complete. step-3-creating-the-release step\ 3\ -\ creating\ the\ release Step 4 - Finalising the Release Finalise Release Builder Fig. 17 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-finalise-release Fig. %s The release is finalised using the(). Finalise Release Builder release_staging_<version number> cellml/libcellml cellml/libcellml https://github.com/cellml/libcellml end-to-end testing framework end-to-end testing framework https://github.com/libcellml/end-to-end-testing end-to-end testing database end-to-end testing database https://github.com/libcellml/end-to-end-test-database Fig. 18 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-finalise-release-builder-interface Fig. %s Fig. 19 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-release-branch-chooser-example Fig. %s Fig. 20 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-end-to-end-framework-tag-chooser-example Fig. %s Fig. 21 std std-numref True libcellml-release-process-end-to-end-database-tag-chooser-example Fig. %s Theinterface interrogatesfor release branches, and, andfor tags. Choose the values for finalising the release in the finalise release interface,. The branch input in the interface should be set to thebranch (again, there should be only one),. The end-to-end testing tag is the tag that specifies the version of the testing framework to use for running the tests,. The end-to-end testing database is the tag that specifies the version of the database that describes the tests to run,. Finalise Release Builder Thewill update the libCellML staging website with the API documentation and the developer documentation. The user documentation will only be updated for the release, if the end-to-end testing passes. To this end, it is important to choose the appropriate end-to-end testing tag and end-to-end testing database tag. If the end-to-end testing passes, the specifics of the versions that the release was tested with will be saved and surfaced on the website. Finalise Release Builder release_staging_<version number> main release_staging_<version number> The last thing that thedoes is the merging of theinto thebranch and the deletion of thebranch. Buildbot finalise release builder interface. {'*': 'images/release_process/finalise_release_builder.png'} images/release_process/finalise_release_builder.png Finalise Release Builder on Buildbot. title: Utilities
content: Utilities LIBCELLML_ENABLE_UTILITIES code TRUE code This document covers the utilities that are available to developers of libCellML. The utilities are not built or made available by default. The utilities can be enabled through the configuration of the library. In order to enable the utilities, set the configuration variableto. The available utilities are: Create MathML DTD files Update generator profile SHA-1 values arabic . Create MathML DTD files mathmldtd.h code mathmldtd.cpp code The create MathML DTD files utility generates a compressed MathML DTD. The MathML DTD is used to determine the validity of MathML strings in a CellML document. This utility updates the header fileand source filein the source tree of the current build. For a make-based environment, the utility may be run with the following command: create-mathml-dtd-files create\ mathml\ dtd\ files Update generator profile SHA-1 values generatorprofilesha1values.h code The update generator profile SHA-1 values utility calculates the SHA-1 values for the current C and Python generator profiles. This utility updates the header filein the source tree of the current build. For a make-based environment, the utility may be run with the following command: update-generator-profile-sha-1-values update\ generator\ profile\ sha-1\ values utilities utilities /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/src/docs/dev_utilities.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Buildingfor use in the Browser
content: libCellML Buildingfor use in the Browser libCellML To buildfor the browser, we use the emscripten toolchain to create web assembly binaries. Here, we will go through the process of building web assembly binaries on macOS. For other operating systems, modifications to these instructions will have to be made. Any modifications required are expected to be self evident – with this in mind these instructions should be universally applicable. Preparation libCellML To buildfor the browser, we will need the following tools ready for use. Emscripten Compiler toolchain CMake (at least version 3.14) Git - preparation preparation Building libCellML libCellML libCellML requires two dependencies to be built beforeitself can be built. We will clone and build those first and then move on to building. Dependencies Start by creating a directory under which all our files will live and make it our current directory for subsequent commands: Now, we can clone our dependencies (we suggest using these exact repositories other repositories may work but these repositories are known to work): We will create two directories to hold the build files: zlib libxml2 zlib not Then, we will configure, build, and installas this is required by. We will installunder our emscripten working directory andinto the system directories: emcmake code zlib Release current source build Here, we have configured the project using the emscripten wrapper script. This script sets up environment variables for us to make building with the emscripten compilers easy. We also configure thelibrary to be built inmode and set the install prefix relative to thedirectory. However, this is not an issue for us as theanddirectories are sibling directories. zlib To build and install thelibrary, we simply issue these commands: libxml2 Next, we follow a similar procedure for building. Start by making the current directory the parent of the zlib build directory: Then, as before, configure the library: There are seven additions to the configure command this time: ZLIB_DIR code libxml2 As a general note, it is better to specify the variableas an absolute path and not a relative path as we have done here. Feel free to use the absolute path when you are configuring. Then, as before, we simply issue the build and install commands: libCellML That is all that is required for preparing the dependencies ready for. ZLIB_DIR code -DZLIB_DIR=../usr/local/lib/cmake/ZLIB-1.2.12/ code zlib We setto enable the configuration to find ourlibrary we just installed,. libxml2 We turn off building a sharedlibrary, -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF. libxml2 We turn off buildingwith iconv, -DLIBXML2_WITH_ICONV=OFF. libxml2 We turn off buildingwith lzma compression, -DLIBXML2_WITH_LZMA=OFF. libxml2 We turn off buildingwith Python, -DLIBXML2_WITH_PYTHON. libxml2 We turn off buildingwith tests, -DLIBXML2_WITH_TESTS=OFF; and libxml2 We turn off buildingwith programs, -DLIBXML2_WITH_PROGRAMS=OFF. arabic . dependencies dependencies libCellML libCellML libCellML Following a similar approach to building the dependencies, we can now configure and build. We don’t installwhen building for web assembly, so there is no install command in the instructions. emscripten code To get started, we will make our current directory thedirectory we made at the start. Assuming we are in the directory where we left off from preparing the dependencies, we simply change to the parent directory: If your current directory is not where the dependency instructions left off then modify the command as appropriate for your situation. git clone code Now, let’s get the source code using: Now, we will create a build directory: We can now configure the library: LibXml2_DIR code As with the earlier note, it is best ifis an absolute path and not a relative path as shown here. The last thing we have to do is build the library: That should be everything done. libcellml libcellml building building Outcome libcellml.js code libcellml.wasm code libcellml.common.js code libcellml.common.wasm code src/bindings/javascript/ code libCellML Given that all of the above worked you should have the following four files,,, andin therelative to thebuild directory where we left off above. outcome outcome Test libCellML libCellML build-libcellml-release code We can test theWebAssembly to make sure everything works. From thebuild directory, we can run the test command: The first time the tests are run the node modules required for running the tests are installed. This can take a while to complete, please be patient while the node modules install. Subsequent running of the tests will not require node modules to be installed and the tests will be run in a much more timely manner. title: Current Thinking for libCellML
content: libcellmlcurrentthinking Current Thinking for libCellML This document simply outlines some of the current rationale that has an influence on how the codebase is developed. Temporarily dealing with external documents that are stored on the local file system (relative to the current CellML model document). Allows testing of the most common model import scenario (local files addressed with a relative URL). Absolves libcellml from fetching files and communicating across the Internet. Expect to provide another layer that would perform this role as a libCellML I/O library, which would allow the removal of this temporary inclusion. No avenue to retrieve remote external references. - Serialise and deserialise from a string. XML False https://www.w3.org/XML/ Present a useful interface not one tied to theserialisation structure. CellML False https://www.cellml.org/ Validation is quite separate (you are free to make invalidmodels). Public API treats MathML as strings only. MathML False https://www.w3.org/Math/ Internal to the code generation we are currently creating our ownobject model based on an abstract syntax tree. Minimal implementation to support the immediate requirement of code generation. Expect to provide another layer that would handle MathML as a separate thing, potentially linking back to the advanced functionality envisions for symbolic analysis of the model. Internal to the validator, the MathML strings are parsed into a DOM for use in schema validation against the MathML schema. - - current-thinking-for-libcellml libcellmlcurrentthinking current\ thinking\ for\ libcellml libcellmlcurrentthinking /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/src/docs/current_thinking.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Coverage Statistics
content: coverage-statistics Coverage Statistics TODO The output from the coverage testing using gcov is available TODO. The coverage test sometimes (this behaviour has been observed on macOS using Clang) reports single lines containing only a closing curly brace as not covered. This is currently being treated as a false positive. This can be seen in the ‘Missing’ column of the test report where only single lines are reported. For the case discussed here, the reported line should only contain a single closing curly brace.
