title: Contributing to libCellML
content: contributing Contributing to libCellML prime repository xref std std-term True glossary#term-prime-repository GitHub False https://github.com/ Git False https://git-scm.com/ Setup std std-ref True setup#setup Building std std-ref True configure_and_build#configure-and-build This document covers the process to follow for getting your changes into the. While there are many types of contribution, this section is focussed on contributions made throughandto assets that are managed using the version control system. It is assumed thatandhave already been read and followed. Overview prime repository xref std std-term True glossary#term-prime-repository For any body of work intended for contribution to the, first start with a Github issue. The issue can be used to discuss the topic and clarify any problems related to it. Once progress has been made towards addressing the issue, a pull request is created that references the issue. Buildbot False https://buildbot.net/ build/test code Reviewers provide feedback on the changes by adding comments to the pull request or associated commits. Theprocedure will run each time changes are pushed to the pull request’s branch, and the results are displayed in the pull request view. prime repository xref std std-term True glossary#term-prime-repository develop code Once all the changes and reviews are complete, one of theowners will merge the pull request into the prime repository, onto thebranch. Note that a bug is just a type of issue, and that resolving the bug should have both the implementation to fix the bug and a test that triggers the bug. Fig. 8 std std-numref True libcellml-development-process Fig. %s gives a graphical overview of the developer contribution process. For more details, see the text below. Developer contribution process. {'*': 'images/libCellMLProcesses-DevelopmentProcess.png'} images/libCellMLProcesses-DevelopmentProcess.png Fig. 8 Developer contribution process. center libcellml-development-process libcellml_development_process overview overview GitHub issues If an issue does not exist for the required work (e.g. implementation of a feature, fixing of a bug), then create a new one. The issue is the place to discuss the particulars related to the issue, discussions on determining the scope of the issue or clarification of any points that are unclear. https://github.com/cellml/libcellml/libCellML repository False https://github.com/cellml/libcellml/libCellML repository Issues code To create a new issue, go to theGitHub page, and select thetab. Use the green button on the right hand side to create a new issue. You will need to add a description of what you’ve encountered, as well as any small snippets of code that help describe it. Labels TODO These are not current? A Github issue may be assigned labels by the project administrators to help identify its status at a glance. General labels currently used for libCellML are: Platform Milestone In addition, alabel may be used to identify the issue as specific to a given platform.labels may be used to project when a feature is expected to be complete and/or indicate the priority of a given issue. Higher priority issues will take precedence and therefore be assigned a more immediate (lower) milestone number. Bug : the issue identifies a malfunction in the current codebase. Feature : the issue constitutes a request or plan for a new feature. Needs tests : the issue requires test(s) to be complete. This may refer to a bug report, contributed code, comments, etc. in the issue. Needs documentation : the issue requires documentation to be complete. This may refer to a bug report, contributed code, comments, etc. in the issue. Needs reviewing : the issue requires further review from project participants to be complete. This may refer to a bug report, contributed code, comments, etc. in the issue. * labels labels github-issues github\ issues Topic branches prime repository xref std std-term True glossary#term-prime-repository prime repository xref std std-term True glossary#term-prime-repository develop code A topic or feature branch is a branch that is local to you (and anyone you collaborate with), it is a branch that will not be available from the. All development work should be carried out on a topic branch, for example any major feature that you work on or minor bug fix. Before creating a local topic branch, pull the latest changes from thebranch, to make sure that you’re working from the most up-to-date version of the code. prime repository xref std std-term True glossary#term-prime-repository develop code Following this process will make it easier to have multiple topic branches at once and keep them in-sync with thebranch, which will in turn make it easier to manage multiple pull requests. issue #123 The following Git commands show an example of how to create a topic branch for fixing a (hypothetical) bug described in: Git branching illustration. {'*': 'images/libCellMLProcesses-GitBranching.png'} images/libCellMLProcesses-GitBranching.png Fig. 9 How branching in a Git repository works. center git-branching git_branching topic-branches topic\ branches Test-driven development Test-driven development entails writing a test (or suite of tests) that covers the intended functionality, and no more. The tests will require some skeleton implementation so that they can compile, but in the first instance they probably won’t pass. Writing the test(s) first shows the other developers the new behaviour that you intend to implement. By making a pull request containing only these tests, other developers can then comment and discuss until everyone is happy with the new behaviour. Following this contribution process allows for corrections before time is spent on the functional code. It may be necessary to refactor the current design to enable the easiest possible way to add the new feature. This is a good thing as the quality of the design improves and this makes it easier to work with in the future. Refactoring means improving the code without adding features, and the tests provide validation that the refactored code performs as well as before. For simple or obvious bugs which have fallen through the testing gaps, simply submitting a pull request with the repaired implementation and no extra tests is fine. test-driven-development test-driven\ development GitHub pull requests Fig. 9 std std-numref True git-branching Fig. %s prime repository xref std std-term True glossary#term-prime-repository develop code Addresses issue #123 code Once some changes have been made and local commits committed, push your changes to your Github libCellML repository (refer to). From there, create a pull request from your topic branch to thebranch. When creating the pull request, make sure to add in the comment(of course, replace the number 123 with the actual number of the issue you are addressing), or something to that effect. This will create a link between the issue and the pull request enabling other people to see that you are working on this issue and comment on your work. The following Git commands show an example of how to add all files, commit the changes, and push them to a Github repository for the first time: git add code git commit code git push code issue123 code issue123 code Theandcommands should be obvious, thecommand sets the local branchto be linked with the remote branchin the origin (the default shorthand for your libCellML repository on Github) repository. This branch will be created in the origin repository if it does not already exist. creating Github pull requests False https://help.github.com/articles/creating-a-pull-request/ To create a pull request from one Github repository to another, follow the instructions for. github-pull-requests github\ pull\ requests Reviewing It may happen that submitted work is not reviewed immediately or the work is finished before any comments have been made. If this is the case add a comment to the pull request asking for the submission to be reviewed. An email will be sent out to the repository owners who will respond and review the submission, please remember that everyone is busy and it may not happen right away. reviewing reviewing Satisfying the feedback It is important to respond to all feedback appropriately, the review process will check to make sure that all comments have been dealt with. Feel free to respond to comments as appropriate, e.g. through code changes, posting a direct reply, etc. Where you need to change code in response to a comment, be sure to include the commit code (a 7 digit hex number) in your reply, so that others can see where and how the changes were made. satisfying-the-feedback satisfying\ the\ feedback Completing prime repository xref std std-term True glossary#term-prime-repository To complete the process, it is required to have two owners of thecomment on the pull request that they are satisfied that the work on the issue is complete and also that the feedback has been addressed, in essence that they are happy to merge the submission. For small submissions, it is sufficient for the second owner to show satisfaction by performing the merge. For larger submissions one of the owners will post a comment on the issue notifying subscribers that they intend to merge the pull request. If no further objections are raised, the pull request will be merged and closed. Review Process std std-ref True review_process#review-process A little reminder for the repository owners to check that thehas been followed before merging the pull request. completing completing contributing-to-libcellml contributing contributing\ to\ libcellml contributing https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/src/docs/contributing.rst

title: Configuring and building libCellML

title: Coding standards
content: coding-standards Coding standards Google C++ Style Guide False https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html The coding standard for libCellML follows that specified in the, but it does not have to be followed to the letter; other people have not so positive opinions about the quality of the Google style guide. The coding standard in use for libCellML is in evidence in the code itself. New code should be consistent with what is already there. In essence, we seek code that looks good, is easy-to-read and has great documentation, and - most importantly - does what it promises to do. We do not want to spend time discussing the minutiae of the coding style. The following is a list of exceptions/deviations from the Google style guide that have been agreed upon for libCellML software development purposes. camelCase False https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camel_case class method names. Indent core code four spaces at a time (no tabs); for CMake files use two space indentation. * Doxygen comments code code std::string code @c code Code-words (e.g.,,) should be styled as typewriter text with a preceding. Doxygen comments should be sentence-style: beginning with capitalisation (except code-words) and ending with punctuation. However, they do not need to form grammatically correct sentences. * doxygen-comments doxygen\ comments Test naming Names should respect the camel case naming convention. Names should be explicit enough to identify the specific code features they cover. * test-naming test\ naming Variable naming The following rules for naming of variables should be followed. mMyClassMemberVariable code Class member variables:. myFunctionParameterVariable code Function parameter variables:. myLocalVariable code Local variables:. * variable-naming variable\ naming Weak pointers std::weak_ptr<T>::lock() code nullptr code The return value ofshould only be tested if it may be equal to. * weak-pointers weak\ pointers coding-standards id1 coding\ standards coding_standards /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/src/docs/coding_standards.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Understanding units
content: understanding-units Understanding units Some basic units have been defined and built into libCellML, others you can define by combining the built-in ones using scaling factors and exponents, or you can define your own from scratch if need be. There are four different kinds of units used here: irreducible units, built-in units, derived or combination units, and custom irreducible units. Irreducible units irreducible The first are calledbecause they represent the physical base quantities which cannot be further simplified: metre code length () second code time () mole code amount of a substance () kelvin code temperature () kilogram code mass () ampere code electrical current () candela code luminous intensity () dimensionless code non-dimensional () - shortlist irreducible Theseunits can be used to create all other physically-based units by combining them using different exponents, multipliers, and prefixes. irreducible-units irreducible\ units Built-in units built-in units Some of these combinations form our second type of units, the, these being common relationships which have been constructed from combinations of the irreducible units. The combinations can involve: built-in Built-in Units table False https://cellml-specification.readthedocs.io/en/latest//reference/formal_and_informative/specC02_units_reference.html#table-built-in-units A list of pre-existingconvenience units is shown in the, along with their relationships to the irreducible units. millisecond code second code A scaling factor (the unitsis equivalent toand a factor of 0.001); coulomb code second code ampere code A combination of units (ais amultiplied by an); hertz code second code Powers of units (ahas a base ofwith an exponent of -1); and Any combination of the above. - shortlist built-in-units built-in\ units Combination or derived units combinations The third type of units are thosewhich users can define for themselves based on the built-in units, the irreducible units, any other units already created, or (see below) their own custom irreducible units. t second code For example, let’s say that you want to simulate the time variable,, in units of milliseconds. This isn’t one of the built-in units, so you’ll need to define it, but it’s easy to see that it’s based on the built-in, but needs a scaling factor. For convenience libCellML gives a variety of options for defining such scaling factors: API Units documentation False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Units?fName=addUnit The overloaded argument option list is shown below for each language. Please check thefor details. reference code StandardUnits code prefix code Note thatcan be another unit name string or aenum, andcan be a string or an integer. Units code To create aitem you need will follow the same basic steps as other entities: declare it, name it, define it, and then add it in. For example: millisecond code per_millisecond code Units can be defined based on one another as well. For example, after defining ourunits, we could then use this definition to define theunits by simply including it with an exponent of -1: Interpretation of Units page False https://cellml-specification.readthedocs.io/en/latest//reference/formal_and_informative/specC03_interpretation_of_units.html millisecond code second code prefix="milli" code Either through the use of named prefixes which are listed on the, eg:iswith; log_{10} 10^{-3}=0.001 millisecond code second code prefix=-3 code prefix="-3" code By defining an integer or integer string as a prefix which represents theof the scaling factor, eg:iswithgives a scaling factor of. title: Understand collections of items
content: understanding-collections Understand collections of items Variable code Component code Units code Model code Where an item can contain more than one child item (for example, more than onein a, more than oneitem in a, etc) the processes for curating that collection follow the patterns outlined below. NB: All of this explanation uses “thing” in place of the specific type of item (component, variable etc). NB: Viewing a model False /documentation/v0.6.3/howto/view_model Editing a model False /documentation/v0.6.3/howto/edit_model This section explains the basic rationale of the collections. For practical information about how they are used, please see theandpages. Count things thingCount() code thing code unitsCount() code Units code Model code Generic counting functions will return the number of child items using thefunction to get the number ofchildren. For example,returns the number ofitems in a. This is useful when iterating through a collection or before using an index to access one of its members. count-things count\ things Get a thing getting taking thing code Pointers to items within a collection can be retrieved in two ways: byor by. The first does not affect the collection, and returns a pointer to the item: this is accomplished using thefunction. There are two overloaded arguments for the get functionality: Note that in this case the retrieval of the thing does not alter it, and neither does it alter the parent which owns it. thing(i) code returns a pointer to the thing at the i-th index position; and thing("myThingName") code returns a pointer to the thing named “myThingName”. - get-a-thing get\ a\ thing Add a thing addThing code addThing(thingToAdd) code thingToAdd code To add to a collection use thefunctionality. The basic form of adding is by symbol:which will append the pointer toto the collection. Special cases of this are: addComponent code Thefunction will return a boolean variable telling you whether the operation was successful or not. In situations where the component has already been included in the collection, is present in another collection, or is not found, this operation will return false. Other add functions do not return any value. addUnit code API addUnit False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Units?fName=addUnit Thefunction has many overloaded argument lists. Please refer to the fullreference for details. - add-a-thing add\ a\ thing Remove one thing removeThing code To remove an item from the collection and detach its parent without returning a pointer to that item, use thefunctions. Because the collections are stored as a group of smart pointers, if no references exist to the item then its contents will also be deleted. If other references do exist, the parent pointer will be detached, but they won’t otherwise be affected. nb remove-one-thing remove\ one\ thing Remove all the things removeAllThings code In addition to the removal of specific items from a collection as above, you can also clear the entire collection using thefunctions. remove-all-the-things remove\ all\ the\ things Take a thing takeThing code thing code removeThing code remove get get Thefunctions combine a little of theand a little of thefunctionality. It will return a pointer to the item (like thefunctionality above), but it will also remove the item from the collection (like), updating both the collection as well as the item’s parent. The item is thus detached from its parent, and “taken” by the returned pointer. Examples are shown for C++ and Python below. Their operation is straightforward: a position within the collection is specified (either using an index, or the name of an existing item in the collection), and a replacement item is supplied. The replacement item overwrites what was previously stored at the position in the collection. In addition, thetakes an optional boolean argument indicating whether to search the encapsulated children for the item, if specified by name. By default this is set to. For more information about replacement, please see the API documentation foranditems directly. only Note that theseoperate on collections of items. title: Constants vs Variables
content: constants-vs-variables Constants vs Variables vary variable code In your model, there is mathematics. And in your mathematics, there are variables. Some of these variables will, well,in value, but others might not. This note is to help you understand the different ways in whichelements are assigned value, and what it means to your whole model’s interpretation. variable code There are six ways to assign a value to aelement: 1. Assign to a number in a math block math code variable code A code never These are classed as “eternal truths”, and are statements which are held to be true throughout the entirety of the simulation. If you use ablock statement to assign value to aelement using a hard-coded numerical value, then that value canbe changed. Any attempt to change it will make the model over-defined. In the example below,is a constant with value 1 for the entire simulation. C++ panel-0-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-0-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-0-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-0-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-0-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-0-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-0-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-0-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element Show CellML header toggle assign-to-a-number-in-a-math-block 1.\ assign\ to\ a\ number\ in\ a\ math\ block 2. Assign to another variable or expression in a math block math code B := C code C := B code assignments equations not B = C C = B B = C As above, these are classed as “eternal truths”, but of course the actual value held by the variables may change as the expression is evaluated at different times. Thestatements are not(as you’d expect in a programming language), but rather(as you’d expect in mathematics). This means that writingis equivalent to writing, just as it is in normal mathematics, and can be read “The value of B is always the same as the value of C”. Compare that to the assignment statement we’re familiar with in programming,(“set the value of B to be the current value of C”) which isthe same as(“set the value of C to be the current value of B”). Of courseis perhaps the simplest equation possible, and yours will be a lot more complicated than this! C++ panel-1-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-1-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-1-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-1-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-1-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-1-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-1-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-1-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element assign-to-another-variable-or-expression-in-a-math-block 2.\ assign\ to\ another\ variable\ or\ expression\ in\ a\ math\ block 3. Assign as an initial value attribute initial_value code math code any may The term “initial value” might lead you to believe that theattributes are only used for variables of integration. In reality,variable which will have a non-constant value during the simulationbe set using this attribute. This includes values which are changed by resets, or by solving a differential or algebraic equation. The only situation where you don’t need to set a variable’s value like this is where the variable is defined by evaluation of ablock statement. In that situation, having an initial value specified as well as a maths definition will make the model over-defined. C++ panel-2-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-2-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-2-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-2-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-2-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-2-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-2-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-2-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element Show CellML header toggle assign-as-an-initial-value-attribute 3.\ assign\ as\ an\ initial\ value\ attribute 4. Assign by solving a differential equation variable code initial_value code must This is similar to point 2 above, in that the variable’s definition is contained within a mathematical statement. The difference is that when aelement is a state variable (ie: the numerator of a differential equation), ithave a value which is specified (either locally or somewhere in its equivalent variable set) by anattribute. C++ panel-3-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-3-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-3-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-3-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-3-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-3-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-3-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-3-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element Show CellML header toggle assign-by-solving-a-differential-equation 4.\ assign\ by\ solving\ a\ differential\ equation 5. Assign by applying a reset equations assignment math code reset_value code Resets allow a variable to have prescribed discontinuity in value at some stage in the simulation process. This means that the value of the variable must be allowed to change (that is, it must not appear in a statement like in point 1 above). In contrast to the mathematicaldefined insideelements, the MathML statements within a reset’sblock is an. By their nature, the mathematics of resets are only temporarily true, and so anything written there is a one-off assignment when the reset item is active. This means that even though the reset variable’s value can’t be defined as a constant (as in point 1), it could still be part of an equation (as in point 2). It must not be a variable of integration (as in point 4) or a base variable (as in point 6). assign-by-applying-a-reset 5.\ assign\ by\ applying\ a\ reset 6. Assign as a variable of integration These don’t need to be given a value inside CellML as their value will be set during the simulation. assign-as-a-variable-of-integration 6.\ assign\ as\ a\ variable\ of\ integration id1 constants\ vs\ variables /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/asides-tested-docs/constant_vs_variable.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: libcellml
content: CellmlElementType The CellmlElementType enum class. This enum describes CellML elements. A CellML element identifies elements in the underlying CellML specification format. title: libcellml::ComponentEntity
content: ComponentEntity classlibcellml_1_1ComponentEntity compound Theclass. The interface class for managing Components. ~ComponentEntity Destructor,. ComponentEntity Copy constructor,. rhs ComponentEntity Move constructor,. rhs operator= Assignment operator,. rhs doEquals Virtual implementation method for equals,. other ComponentEntity Forward declaration for pImpl idiom,. Constructor for derived classes,. pImpl pFunc Getter for private implementation pointer,. pFunc Const getter for private implementation pointer,. addComponent Add a child component to this component entity. Add the given component as a child component of this component entity. If the given component doesn't have a parent then this component entity will be set as its parent. If the given component does have a parent then the given component will have this component entity set as its parent and its old parent will no longer have the given component as a child. If the addition of the given component creates a cycle of components the given component will not be added to this component entity and it will not have this component entity set as its parent. The component will keep its current parent and it will remain a child of its current parent. component The component to add. param True if the component was added, false otherwise. return component removeComponent index Remove the component at the given. index index Remove the component with the given.must be in the range [0, #components). index The index of the component to remove. param True if the component was removed, false otherwise. return index removeComponent This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts. name Remove the component with the given. name searchEncapsulated Remove the first component found that matches the given. Ifis(default) this will also search for the named component through this component's encapsulated components. name The name of the component to remove. searchEncapsulated name Boolean flag to indicate whether we should also search encapsulated components for the component with the specified. Default value is. param True if the component was removed, false otherwise. return name searchEncapsulated removeComponent This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. Default value is. param True if the component was removed, false otherwise. return component searchEncapsulated removeAllComponents Remove all components stored in this component entity. title: libcellml::AnalyserModel
content: AnalyserModel classlibcellml_1_1AnalyserModel compound Theclass. AnalyserModel classlibcellml_1_1AnalyserModel compound Analyser classlibcellml_1_1Analyser compound Theclass is for representing a model in the context of a CellML. Type The type of a model. The type of a model, i.e. whether it is unknown, invalid, underconstrained, overconstrained, or unsuitably constrained, or whether it defines a system of algebraic equations, a system of non-linear algebraic equations, a system of ordinary differential equations, or a system of differential algebraic equations. AnalyserModel classlibcellml_1_1AnalyserModel compound Model classlibcellml_1_1Model compound Model classlibcellml_1_1Model compound To test for equivalence is time consuming, so caching is used to speed things up. During the analysis of a model, various tests are performed and their result cached. So, if you test two variables that were tested during the analysis then the cached result will be returned otherwise the two variables will be properly tested and their result cached. This works because analways refers to a static version of a. However, this might break if ais modified after it has been analysed. variable1 Variable classlibcellml_1_1Variable compound variable2 Theto test if it is equivalent to. variable2 Variable classlibcellml_1_1Variable compound variable1 Thethat is potentially equivalent to. param variable1 variable2 ifis equivalent toandotherwise. return variable1 variable2 typeAsString Type classlibcellml_1_1AnalyserModel_1a2df8a5f70631d57d478756180810adfd member Get the string version of a. title: libcellml::AnalyserExternalVariable
content: AnalyserExternalVariable classlibcellml_1_1AnalyserExternalVariable compound Theclass. AnalyserExternalVariable classlibcellml_1_1AnalyserExternalVariable compound Analyser classlibcellml_1_1Analyser compound GeneratorProfile::externalVariableMethodTypeDefinitionString classlibcellml_1_1GeneratorProfile_1ad41ac2a0d47d82a7fe1da22b9252fc4e member GeneratorProfile::setExternalVariableMethodTypeDefinitionString classlibcellml_1_1GeneratorProfile_1ad0f95a069343e940af0692ac4d294027 member Theclass is for representing an external variable in the context of a CellML, i.e. a variable which is not set or computed by this model, but set externally. It is therefore the responsibility of the user to set an external variable (seeand). Also, say that the analysis of a model fails because the type of one or several of its variables could not be determined (i.e. the model is underconstrained). To add those variables as external variables will allow the analysis to succeed. This is because the analyser will have considered those variables as initialised. Once again, it is the responsibility of the user to ensure that it all makes sense. mPimpl Private member to implementation pointer,. ~AnalyserExternalVariable Destructor,. The type of a node in an abstract syntax tree (AST), i.e. whether it is an equality type, a relational or a logical operator, an arithmetic operator, a calculus element, a trigonometric operator, a piecewise statement, a token element, a qualifier element, or a constant. title: Tutorial 5: Annotation tools
content: tutorial5 Tutorial 5: Annotation tools By the time you have worked through this tutorial you will be able to: Model code Parse a CellML file into ainstance; Determine the type of item which has a given id; Annotator code Use theclass to retrieve an item using only its id string; Repair duplicated id strings within the model scope; and Automatically generate and assign unique ids to any or all items. - shortlist Requirements C++ resources Python resources CellML resources CMakeLists.txt xref download 401b8d450f99919675ecd02493097527/CMakeLists.txt tutorial5/index True CMakeLists.txt download False The CMake file for building this tutorial; and AnotherMysteryModel.cellml xref download c6bfd7055bb132920fde54c0470fc429/AnotherMysteryModel.cellml tutorial5/index True AnotherMysteryModel.cellml download False its import dependency. - directorylist requirements requirements Background Annotator code “Marco Polo” is a game played with many people in a swimming pool. One person calls “Marco” with their eyes closed. Others answer “Polo” and the first person must find them by following the sound. In this tutorial you are given id strings and a mystery CellML model file. We will work through how theclass can be used to locate the desired objects. background background Step 1: Parse the mystery model 1.a Read the file “MysteryModel.cellml” into a string. dothis 1.b Parser code Create aitem. dothis 1.c Use the parser to deserialise the contents of the string you’ve read and return the model. dothis 1.d Check that the parser has not raised any issues. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-1-parse-the-mystery-model step\ 1:\ parse\ the\ mystery\ model Step 2: Retrieve an item with a unique id Annotator class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator Tutorial functions create False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=create setModel False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=setModel item False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=item issueCount False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=issueCount issue False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=issue - cellmlElementTypeAsString code CellmlElementType code C++:will return a string version of theenumeration cellmlElementTypeAsString code Python: - useful 2.a Annotator code setModel code Create anitem and use itsfunction to pass in the parsed mystery model. item code libcellml::AnyItem code std::pair code libcellml::CellmlElementType code std::any code In C++: Thefunction returns a, awhose first attribute is aenumeration; and second attribute is acast of the item itself. item code CellmlElementType code In Python: Thefunction returns a tuple. The first item is aenumeration, the second is the item itself. - dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 2.b Retrieve the item with an id of “marco”. Use the helper function to convert the enumeration of its type into a string, and print to the terminal. dothis 2.c Check that the annotator has not reported any issues. dothis 2.d std::any_cast code (C++ only) Cast the second attribute of the macro item into a libcellml::VariablePtr item using. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-2-retrieve-an-item-with-a-unique-id step\ 2:\ retrieve\ an\ item\ with\ a\ unique\ id Step 3: Retrieve items whose id are not unique Annotator class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator items False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=items isUnique False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=isUnique assignId False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=assignId - useful 3.a Now try the same procedure to find the item with id of “polo”. Retrieve the item and print its type to the terminal. dothis 3.b UNDEFINED code The item type returned is… so we need to check what the annotator has to say about it. Retrieve the issues from the annotator and print them to the terminal. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.c items code Since the id is not unique, we need to retrieve all items with that id for investigation. Use thefunction to retrieve the vector of items with id “polo”, and iterate through it printing the different types to the terminal. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.d UNIT code Assign an automatic id to all of the items with id “polo”, except for the one whose type is. dothis 3.e isUnique code Check that the id of “polo” is now unique in the model by calling thefunction. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Annotator class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator Unit class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Unit component False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=component componentRef False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=componentRef connection False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=connection encapsulation False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=encapsulation import False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=import mapVariables False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=mapVariables model False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=model reset False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=reset resetValue False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=resetValue testValue False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=testValue unit False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=unit units False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=units variable False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Annotator?fName=variable - units False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Unit?fName=units index False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Unit?fName=index - useful 3.f Unit code Unit code Retrieve thewith id “polo” directly. Theclass has two attributes: units() code Units code returns the parentitem; and index() code returns the index of this unit within its parent. - dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle UNIT code Annotator code assignId code The item we want has type, and we’d like it to be unique so that we can annotate it properly. We need to change the other items to have other (also unique) ids. Theclass can create a unique id for an item using thefunction. UNIT code Now we know that there is only one item in the model with id “polo”, and we also know that it has type. In circumstances where you know the type of the item with the id you’re fetching ahead of time, you can retrieve it without the need to cast using the direct functions according to type: these are listed below. step-3-retrieve-items-whose-id-are-not-unique step\ 3:\ retrieve\ items\ whose\ id\ are\ not\ unique Step 4: Discover items whose ids are unknown Now that we’ve found Marco and fixed the duplicates of Polo, we’d like to know what other ids are being used in this model. assignId code The hex strings printed are those which have been automatically generated by thefunction; we can also see the “marco” and “polo” ids as expected. title: Tutorial 3: Create a model and generate code using the API
content: tutorial3 Tutorial 3: Create a model and generate code using the API By the time you have worked through Tutorial 3 you will be able to: Create a new model and its child entities from scratch using the API; Write your own MathML syntax to construct governing equations; Define custom combinations of built-in units; Define your own custom units independent from the built-in units; and Generator code Use thefunctionality to transform the model into other languages. - shortlist This tutorial assumes that you are comfortable with: Tutorial 2 std std-ref True ../tutorial2/index#tutorial2 Accessing and adjusting names of items inside a model hierarchy (see); The population of fish can only grow when they are not being constantly eaten by sharks, and the rate at which is grows will depend on how many fish are available for breeding. At the same time, the population of sharks will depend on how much food is available in the fish population. In maths this relationship can be written: (a, b, c, d)=(-0.8, 0.3, 1.2, -0.6) y_s(t=0)=1.0 y_f(t=0)=2.0 where the constantsand we’ll use the initial conditions ofand. Generator code In order to model these unusual populations you’ll need to create your own custom units, to enter and check these governing equations in MathML syntax, and to use thefunctionality to create files able to be solved using a numerical integrator in C++ or Python. \frac{dy_s}{dt} =f(sharks, fishes, time) = a y_s + b y_s y_f \frac{dy_f}{dt} =f(sharks, fishes, time) = c y_f + d y_s y_f tutorial3/index True False True preserve overview overview Step 1: Set up the governing equations Tutorial 2 std std-ref True ../tutorial2/index#tutorial2 Model code Component code Just as you did in, we need to start by setting up ainstance, and creating ainside it. Tutorial 2 std std-ref True ../tutorial2/index#tutorial2 Variable code Component code Now for the real bit. In order to actually model anything, we need to include the mathematical equations which represent the physical situation of interest. As you saw in, the maths and theitems which it references live inside a parentitem. The system of equations which describe the populations are given by: y_s y_f (a, b, d)=(-0.8, 0.3, -0.6) c Analyser code whereandare the number of sharks and thousands of fish respectively, and the constantsgovern their behaviour. It’s clear that the value of constantis easily calculable from the first equation, but we will leave it in this form to better illustrate the operation of thelater on. W3 resource pages regarding MathML2 False https://www.w3.org/TR/MathML2/chapter4.html#id.4.2.1.3 In order to use this in our model we need to write it as a MathML2 string. The basic structure for these is described in the. It’s highly unlikely that you - the user - will actually be required to write MathML2 code directly, so this part of the tutorial is more about understanding what’s going on under the hood than practising fundamentally necessary skills. c = a - 2.0 Looking at the top equation first, the MathML2 representation ofis: Four things can be seen here: \frac{dx}{dt} Differential terms, such as those on the left-hand side of equations 2 and 3in MathML become: Two further items to note: <apply>...</apply> code The right-hand side becomes a collection of nested operations, all bracketed bytags for each operation: <apply> code <eq/> code When both sides are defined we need to equate them by-ing theequals operator, and turn it into a string. <math> ... </math> code Next you need to define the namespace in which the maths will be applied by enclosing it in thetags with the two namespaces: It’s simple to do this once in your code using a string to represent the opening attributes and namespaces; this string can be reused easily throughout your code as needed later. Our last step in defining the mathematics is to link it into the component. The functions available to manipulate maths are: You should see an output similar to that shown below: Tutorial 2 std std-ref True ../tutorial2/index#tutorial2 Running the validator will alert you variables in the MathML that don’t (yet) exist in your component. This was explained in, and we’ll add them below. 1.a Model code Create a newand give it a name. These variables are referred to as,or. <diff/> code Theoperation signifies differentiation with respect to the base variable. - xmlns code http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML the MathML2 namespaceat xmlns:cellml code http://www.cellml.org/cellml/2 http://www.cellml.org/cellml/2 the CellML2 namespaceat.0# - setMath(yourMathsHere) code Component code Afunction, which overwrites any existing MathML strings stored in theitem; and appendMath(yourMathsHere) code Component code Anfunction, which performs a straightforward string concatenation with the current contents of the maths string in the. setMath code There is no specific function to remove maths from a component, but this can be accomplished by using thefunction with an empty string. - step-1-set-up-the-governing-equations step\ 1:\ set\ up\ the\ governing\ equations Step 2: Create the variables Variable class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Variable Component class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component create False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Variable?fName=create setName False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Variable?fName=setName - addVariable False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component?fName=addVariable - useful 2.a Variable code Createitems for each of the missing variables discovered above. Remember that: setName code Each must have a name, either using the naming constructor or by manually calling thefunction; and Each name must match what’s used inside your MathML string. - dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 2.b addVariable code Add each of your new variables to the component using thefunction. dothis 2.c Call the validator again to check for issues. At this stage you can expect errors like those below relating to missing units for the variables. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-2-create-the-variables step\ 2:\ create\ the\ variables Step 3: Built-in and customised units name means Understanding units False /documentation/v0.6.3/aside/understanding_units Linking variables to theof their units is straightforward, but in order to be able to use them we need to also define what the name actuallyby creating the units themselves. Some common units have been defined and built into libCellML, others you can define by combining the built-in ones using scaling factors and exponents, or you can define your own from scratch if need be. You can read more about units on thepage. Units code To create aitem you need will follow the same basic steps as other entities: declare it, name it, define it, and then add it in. For example: millisecond code per_millisecond code Units can be defined based on one another as well. For example, after defining ourunits, we could then use this definition to define theunits by simply including it with an exponent of -1: b code d code Finally we need to create the units for the constantsand. These will be combinations of those which we’ve already created, as defined by the need for dimensional consistency in our governing equations. The final two steps are to associate each variable with its appropriate units, and to include the units in the model. <cn>2.0</cn> code cellml code In the first MathML equation we used a real numberwithout specifying any units for it. Because the dimensionality of the equation needs to be valid, all real numbers must be associated with units, just the same way that variables are. These are defined within the tags of the MathML, and must also refer to thenamespace. For example: Variable code Units code … which gives us one bunch of bananas, without needing to create a correspondingitem. Of course, you may need to create the correspondingitem and add it to the model, if it is not already present. Remember that you will need to re-include the opening and closingtags as well as the other equations. dothis 3.h Check that the model is now free of validation errors. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-3-built-in-and-customised-units step\ 3:\ built-in\ and\ customised\ units Step 4: Analyse the mathematical model Analyser code Validator code Analyser code Theclass checks that the underlying mathematical model represented by the entire combination of variables, components, and mathematics, makes sense. Thechecks your “spelling” and syntax, and thechecks for the ability to find a solution. Generator code setInitialValue code a, b, c, d code setInitialValue code The messages above refer to the fact that though our model has passed validation tests, it’s not yet sufficiently constrained to allow it to be solved, which is what thechecks for. We need to set initial conditions for the variables we’re solving for, the populations of sharks and fish, using thefunction. The values of the constantsare just that - constant - and their values are set using the samefunction. Analyser class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Analyser create False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Analyser?fName=create analyseModel False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Analyser?fName=analyseModel model False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Analyser?fName=model - useful 4.a Analyser code analyseModel code Create aninstance and pass it the model using thefunction. dothis 4.b printIssues code Check for issues found in the analyser. You should expect 6 errors, related to variables whose values are not computed or initialised. Note that you can use the same utility functionto output issues from the analyser as from the validator. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 4.c (a, b, d)=(-0.8, 0.3, -0.6) y_f(t=0)=2.0 y_s(t=0)=1.0 Set the values of the constantsand the initial conditions such thatand. Note that: c The constantwill be calculated by our equation 1, so does not need to be specified; and t not The base variable (or “variable of integration”, or “voi”)musthave an initial condition set. - dothis 4.d Reprocess the model and check that the analyser is now free of issues. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-4-analyse-the-mathematical-model step\ 4:\ analyse\ the\ mathematical\ model Step 5: Generate code and output Some exciting new functionality in libCellML is the ability to generate a runnable file from a model description. This means that if you already have a solver in either C or Python, you can simply translate your model from here into that language. Generator code beyond Thehas to re-interpret all of the maths, including the variables, their interaction with each other in different equations, values, initial conditions and units before it can output your model in your choice of language. For the maths to make sense, the definitions in your model’s variables, maths blocks and units need to be solvable too. There are several requirements that need to be satisfied in order for the code generation functionality to be able to work,the CellML syntax requirements. These are: GeneratorProfile code The generator takes the CellML model and turns it into procedural code in another language. The default is C, but Python is available too. This language choice is called the “profile”, and is stored in aitem. Generator code The default profile already exists inside theyou’ve just created. We need to edit that profile a little, but only to tell it the file name where they interface (header file) code will be written. This is so that the implementation code (source file) knows where to look when it tries to include it. GeneratorProfile code The generator takes the CellML model and turns it into procedural code in another language. The default is C, but Python is available too. This language choice is called the “profile”, and is stored in aitem. The mathematical model definition must be appropriately constrained (not over- or under-constrained); Initial conditions must be specified for variables which are integrated; Initial conditions must not be specified for variables which are the base of integration; The values of constants must be specified or calculable; and TODO get full list of stuff here … - Generator class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Generator GeneratorProfile class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1GeneratorProfile GeneratorProfile::Profile code GeneratorProfile.Profile code The GeneratorProfile class contains an enum indicating the language of profile to set. In C++ this is. In Python this is. At the time of writing two profiles are available: create False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Generator?fName=create profile False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Generator?fName=profile setModel False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Generator?fName=setModel interfaceCode False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Generator?fName=interfaceCode implementationCode False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Generator?fName=implementationCode - create False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1GeneratorProfile?fName=create setInterfaceFileNameString False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1GeneratorProfile?fName=setInterfaceFileNameString - C code (default) PYTHON code - useful 5.a Generator code model code setModel code Create ainstance. Instead of giving it the model to process, the generator needs an analysed model as its argument. Retrieve the analysed model using the analyser’sfunction and pass it to the generator using thefunction. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 5.b setInterfaceFileNameString code Retrieve the C profile from the generator, and use itsfunction to pass in the same filename that you’ll use in 5.c below for the interface code. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 5.c Since we’re using the default profile (C), we need to output both the interface code (the header file) and the implementation code (the source file) from the generator and write them to their respective files. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 5.d GeneratorProfile code setProfile code Create aitem using the Profile::PYTHON enum value in the constructor. Pass this profile to thefunction in the generator. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 5.e *.py code Retrieve the Python implementation code (there is no header file) and write to afile. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Go and have a cuppa, you’re done! dothis step-5-generate-code-and-output step\ 5:\ generate\ code\ and\ output tutorial-3-create-a-model-and-generate-code-using-the-api tutorial3 tutorial\ 3:\ create\ a\ model\ and\ generate\ code\ using\ the\ api tutorial3 /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/tutorials-tested-docs/tutorial3/index.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Tutorial 2: Debugging, issue checking and validating
content: tutorial2 Tutorial 2: Debugging, issue checking and validating Validator code In this tutorial you’ll explore how theobject can be put to use as you create and interact with your models to help you debug and find issues ahead of submitting it for simulation. You’ll be taking a CellML2.0 file which has some mistakes in it, using the validation functionality to identify them, and then using the access and editing functions to fix them. By the time you have worked through Tutorial 2 you will be able to: Parser code Use theto report issues encountered when reading a file or deserialising a string; and Validator code Use theto check for issues related to a model’s description as compared to the CellML2.0 specifications. - shortlist This tutorial assumes that you can already: Tutorial 1 std std-ref True ../tutorial1/index#tutorial1 Read and deserialise a CellML model from a file (as in); Retrieve the name and id of models, components, and variables; Navigate through the hierarchy of the model and its subsidiary elements (components, variables, units and MathML blocks); and Model code Serialise and print astructure to a CellML file. - shortlist Requirements C++ resources Python resources CellML resources CMakeLists.txt xref download dd20dde845f72d41641ba27873d9833c/CMakeLists.txt tutorial2/index True CMakeLists.txt download False The CMake file for building; This has one job: to make sure that what you give it isin terms of its CellML2.0 compliance. Does it mean that your simulations will work the way you expect? Nope, you can still write rubbish! You can think of the validation being the spell-checker for your model. It doesn’t judge the meaning ofyou’ve written, just the nitty-gritty ofyou’ve written it. The validator can also help you as you create and edit models by pointing out what’s missing or incorrect as you go. This is really easy: Validator code Issue code When you’ve created aobject and called it to check a model, a record of any issues is stored inside the validator. To figure out what’s going on, you need to retrieve the pointers to theseobjects. Tutorial 1 std std-ref True ../tutorial1/index#tutorial1 count code issueCount() code Validator code As in, we can call afunction (in the case of a validator, this is thefunction to determine whether any issues have been raised. Note that an issue a can have different levels: errors, warnings, hints, and messages. In the, only those issues which are errors indicate validation problems, but it’s usually a good idea to check all the issues anyway. Now we need to create an iterative loop to retrieve all the issues (and there should be a few in this particular model!) from the validator. Again following the same retrieval idiom as in Tutorial 1 for items in sets, we can access the issues using an index: Issue code description code referenceHeading code url code Inside anstructure are three fields which are really useful. These are the(which does what you’d think) and the, which points you to the section in the CellML2.0 specification document for reference, and awith links to a relevant website for more information. Each issue also has a level indicator, one of: item code cellmlElementType code CellmlElementType code As well as storing text-based information, the issue also keeps track of which item has the problem. This can be accessed using thefunction, and has a type given by the enumeration infunction. Theenumeration contains: Two utility functions have been provided which will convert the enums for error level or element type into a string for printing. shortlist 2.c Create a loop (to the number of issues found in 2.c) to retrieve each issue pointer. For each issue, retrieve and print as much information as you can. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-2-validate-the-model step\ 2:\ validate\ the\ model Step 3: Fix the issues raised Issue code reader programmer Now that we know what’s wrong with the model the next steps are to fix it! A useful feature of theitems is as well as the textual information (which is more valuable to a), we also have a pointer to the item itself (which is more valuable to aor user). This section will work through the issues reported by the validator, and demonstrate different ways of accessing and repairing each of the problems. setName code component code Model code code code The first issue raised involves the name of a variable. Note that even though the name is invalid (as per CellML specification), it can still be used to access the item. Our first step is to retrieve the badly named variable from the model, then we can use thefunction to repair it. You’ll notice that the name of the component is given too. Because component names are unique in the model, this means that we can use the combination of component name and variable name to retrieve the variable. Thefunction of theclass takes an optional second argument: this is a boolean indicating whether to search for the given component name in the model’s top level components (, the default), or the entirety of the component tree (). Issue code math() code MATH code Inside theclass are helper functions which allow you to access the item which needs to be fixed. The naming of these functions is pretty straightforward, but there’s a catch. Not all of the “items” returned actually exist as independent libCellML entities; some are referenced by their parent item instead. For example, calling thefunction on an issue which reports storing an item with typereturns a pointer to the component item that the maths sits within. The functions and the types they return are shown below. item() code For this next issue we’re going to show how to use thefunction on an issue. This error is similar in implication to that in 3.b: the validator is reporting that it can’t find the units required by a variable. It could be fixed in two different ways: either by supplying units called “i_dont_exist”; or by changing the name of the units which the variable requires to one that is available. Logger code issueCount code issue code This issue was actually also caught by the parser, which, like the validator, is aclass. This means that it will keep track of anything it encounters when parsing a model. You can try calling theandfunctions on the parser and iterating through them (just like in 2.c) to see what you find. MATH code math() code item() code ComponentPtr code As discussed earlier, the type of item stored doesn’t always match the type of item returned. In this final example, the type stored isbut, according to the table above, the type returned from both theandfunctions is (after casting, if required) a. We don’t need to take action to resolve this issue, since our earlier change of the variable name to become “a” will have sorted out the problem already. title: Tutorial 1: Reading and writing CellML files
content: tutorial1 Tutorial 1: Reading and writing CellML files How-to pages False /documentation/v0.6.3/howto Welcome to the introductory tutorial for the use of the libCellML library. Using these tutorials in sequence will walk you through the functionality and build your knowledge step by step. If, however, you just need to jump in and figure out one specific idea, you can find a tutorial related to that subject using the. After completing this tutorial you will be able to: Read the contents of a CellML file; Parser code Model code Deserialise its contents using theto create astructure; Model code Components code Variables code Investigate the hierarchical contents of the, including the,, and MathML blocks; and Printer code Serialise the model and write to another file using the. - shortlist Requirements C++ resources Python resources CellML resources CMakeLists.txt xref download 05df843471d97ff38d2b61d5723e0f16/CMakeLists.txt tutorial1/index True CMakeLists.txt download False The CMake file for building; tutorial1.cpp xref download eb9fdef1eeb699ae47eb40ef05b9f489/tutorial1.cpp tutorial1/index True tutorial1.cpp download False The skeleton code or tutorial1_complete.cpp xref download d247c5578c7174853d8f2bf386e5946c/tutorial1_complete.cpp tutorial1/index True tutorial1_complete.cpp download False the completed code. - tutorial1.py xref download e19cb4319420ff8dde13d71b17d33615/tutorial1.py tutorial1/index False tutorial1.py download False The skeleton code or tutorial1_complete.py xref download eea4811adadfa3ba20d46cc1ac405d87/tutorial1_complete.py tutorial1/index False tutorial1_complete.py download False the completed code. - tutorial1.cellml xref download 4c7ce3c8be8e53e6e2e8fe6038e4da66/tutorial1.cellml tutorial1/index True tutorial1.cellml download False the input CellML file. - directorylist requirements requirements Step 0: Set-up _complete code For each of the tutorials, there is template code provided for you to get started. In order for this information to be transformed into a format which can befor modelling and simulation it needs to beinto the internalformat. The hard work of this transformation is done by theobject which will take a raw CellML string which represents a model and return its correspondingitem. deserialised Now we have aCellML model which we can manipulate using the libCellML library. Parser class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Parser create False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Parser?fName=create parseModel False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Parser?fName=parseModel - useful 1.a tutorial1.cellml code You’ve been provided with a CellML file which we’ll be reading in this tutorial,. Open the file and read its entire contents into a string. dothis 1.b Parser code parseModel code Model code Create ainstance. Pass the string you read above into the parser using thefunction. This will return a newly-createdinstance. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-1-deserialise-a-cellml2-file step\ 1:\ deserialise\ a\ cellml2\ file Step 2: Investigate the contents of the model Now that we have a model, let’s see what’s inside it. All retrieval functions - where you want to read something about any item - are callable from simple functions naming the thing you want. name() code For example, to find the name of the model we simply call itsfunction to return the string of its name. Model code Units code Component code somethingCount() code Something code Theitself stores two kinds of objects: a set ofobjects, and a set ofobjects. There are genericfunctions which will return the number ofitems within that object: know code Items like components and units (and later, variables) which are stored in sets can be accessed by their index as well as by their name. At this stage, since we don’tthe name of the components, we’ll have to use their indices to access them for printing to the terminal. The indices start at. Component code Units code Variable code ComponentPtr code Eachitself (or later,or) is retrieved from its parent item as a pointer (that is, atype) using the same idiom as the names and ids: Component code items in turn contain four kinds of items, these being: In this tutorial we’ll only look at the variables and maths. The implementation filehas two types of items: It’s important to remember that in the generated code we don’t have the notion of separate components: they are listed here with the variables only in order to give the correct context to the variable names. COMPUTED_CONSTANT code CONSTANT code ALGEBRAIC code VariableType code VariableInfoWithType code VARIABLE_INFO code VARIABLE_COUNT code TODO “Variables” are anything which does not require integration as part of the solution, and could have types(needs to be calculated but doesn’t need integration),(no calculation needed), or() as defined in theenum. They are stored in an array ofstructs calledwhich islong. VariableInfo code STATE_INFO code STATE_COUNT code “State variables” are those which need integration. They are stored in an array ofstructs calledwhich islong. information structures (in all-caps); and access functions. - VariableInfoWithType code Thecontains: name, units, component, and VariableType. - shortlist 2.a VARIABLE_INFO code Get the number of variables and iterate through thestructure to retrieve and print each variable’s information to the terminal. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle VariableInfo code Thestruct contains: name, units, and component. - shortlist 2.b STATE_INFO code Get the number of state variables and iterate through thestructure to retrieve and print each state variable’s information to the terminal. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 2.c VariableInfo code VOI_INFO code Get the integration variable and print its information to the terminal. This is stored in astruct called. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-2-access-the-variables-in-the-generated-files step\ 2:\ access\ the\ variables\ in\ the\ generated\ files Step 3: Access the functions in the generated files C++ panel-1-1-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-0 1-0 tab 0 Python panel-1-1-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-1 1-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist The generated code contains seven functions: createStatesArray() code STATE_COUNT code to allocate an array of length. This can be used to allocate the “rates” or gradient function array too as they’re the same length; createVariablesArray() code VARIABLE_COUNT code to allocate an array of length; deleteArray() code to free memory used by the given array; initialiseStatesAndConstants(states, variables) code will do what it says on the tin, and populate the given pre-allocated arrays with the initial values for all of the model’s state variables and constants. computeComputedConstants(variables) code will fill in values for any variables that do not change in value throughout the solution, but still need to be calculated; computeRates(VOI, states, rates, variables) code updates the rates array with the gradients of the state variables, given the values of the other variables and the variable of integration (VOI); computeVariables(VOI, states, rates, variables) code updates any non-integrated variables whose values do not affect the integration. Since this doesn’t affect the solution process it only needs to be called whenever the values need to be output; not necessarily each integration timestep. - tab-1-1-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-1-1-0 1-0 tabpanel 0 The generated code contains seven functions: create_states_array() code STATE_COUNT code to allocate an array of length. This can be used to allocate the “rates” or gradient function array too as they’re the same length; create_variables_array() code VARIABLE_COUNT code to allocate an array of length; delete_array() code to free memory used by the given array; initialise_states_and_constants(states, variables) code will do what it says on the tin, and populate the given pre-allocated arrays with the initial values for all of the model’s state variables and constants. compute_computed_constants(variables) code will fill in values for any variables that do not change in value throughout the solution, but still need to be calculated; compute_rates(VOI, states, rates, variables) code updates the rates array with the gradients of the state variables, given the values of the other variables and the variable of integration (VOI); compute_variables(VOI, states, rates, variables) code updates any non-integrated variables whose values do not affect the integration. Since this doesn’t affect the solution process it only needs to be called whenever the values need to be output; not necessarily each integration timestep. - tab-1-1-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-1-1-1 1-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element 3.a Create three arrays representing: Create and initialise a variable of integration, time. the variables (which here includes constants); the states (the integrated variables); and the rates. - dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.b Use the functions provided to initialise the states array you created, then print them to the screen for checking. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.c Compute the constants, compute the variables, and print them to the screen for checking. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-3-access-the-functions-in-the-generated-files step\ 3:\ access\ the\ functions\ in\ the\ generated\ files Step 4: Iterate through the solution This part will make use of a simple routine to step through the solution iterations using the Euler method to update the state variables. x[n+1] = x[n] + x'[n].dx The Euler update method is: 4.a Create variables which control how the solution will run, representing: step size; and the number of steps to take. - dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 4.b Create a file for output and open it. We will parse the model, resolve its imports, flatten into an import-free model, validate, analyse, and generate. By this stage you should be familiar with most of these processes: we’ll go through the code generation in detail at the end. Step 1: Parse the existing membrane model Parse the model in the “MembraneModel.cellml” file provided and print its contents to the terminal. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-1-parse-the-existing-membrane-model step\ 1:\ parse\ the\ existing\ membrane\ model Step 2: Resolve the imports and flatten In all of the other tutorials we’ve used a flattened model only to analyse its mathematics. This time, we need to keep the flattened version and will use this as input to the code generator. Resolve the imports, and create a flattened version of the model. We do not expect any issues to be reported by the importer. 2.a Create an Importer instance and use it to resolve the imports in your model. dothis 2.b Check that the importer has not raised any issues. dothis 2.c Use the importer to create a flattened version of the model. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-2-resolve-the-imports-and-flatten step\ 2:\ resolve\ the\ imports\ and\ flatten Step 3: Validate and analyse the flattened model You know what to do … we do not expect any issues to be raised by either the validator or the analyser. 3.a Validator code Create ainstance, pass in the flattened model, and check that there are no issues raised. dothis 3.b Analyser code Create aninstance, pass in the flattened model, and check that there are no issues raised. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-3-validate-and-analyse-the-flattened-model step\ 3:\ validate\ and\ analyse\ the\ flattened\ model Step 4: Generate code and output Generator code GeneratorProfile code Theis a translator class that will change the CellML model and its MathML equations into a representation in another language. This is done using ato specify a dictionary of mathematical operations. Two profiles are already defined; for C++ and for Python. Model code Generator code Analyser code AnalyserModel code Instead of submitting aitem (as we do for all other classes), theclass will work from something which has already been processed by theclass: anobject.
