This means that you’re responsible for finding, opening and reading thefile into a single string. The parser will then read that string and return a model. 1.a Read a CellML file into a string. dothis 1.b Parser code Create aitem. dothis 1.c Use the parser to deserialise the contents of the string you’ve read into a model. dothis 1.d Print the parsed model to the terminal for viewing. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-1-parse-the-existing-sodium-channel-model step\ 1:\ parse\ the\ existing\ sodium\ channel\ model Step 2: Validate the parsed model Validator code Create aitem and use it to validate the model you’ve just read. 2.a Validator code Create aitem and validate the model. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 2.b Retrieve any issues from the validator and print them to the terminal. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-2-validate-the-parsed-model step\ 2:\ validate\ the\ parsed\ model Step 3: Repair the parsed model The messages returned from the validator (and other classes) should (!) have enough information to enable you to know what the problem is. In the case of the validator class, the URL listed contains additional resources and examples related to the issue, as well as its section in the CellML normative specification. Issue code In some situations more than onewill be generated from a single cause: this is the case with issues 0 and 1 here: As with 3.a, here we have more than one issue generated from the same cause: in this case, we haven’t specified units for a variable. Each issue generated contains a pointer to the item to which it refers. We can retrieve the affected item directly from the issue in one of two ways: Unit code The error below indicates that a childreferences something which can’t be found. You have a few different options for how to fix this one. The final validator issue refers to the fact that we need to explicitly specify how other components can access each of the variables in this component. 3.a Component code code setName code Fetch the component using its name, and set the name to something valid. Note that when finding aitem, setting an optional second argument towill search the entire encapsulation hierarchy for a component with that name, and not only the direct children of the model. You can follow the URL for information about what makes a valid name, and use thefunction to fix it. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.b The messages above indicate that we’re missing a Units item named “mS_per_cm2”. Create an appropriate Units item (note that S stands for “siemens”), and add it to your model. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.c CellmlElementType::VARIABLE code cellmlElementType() code Check that the item to be returned from the issue is in fact anby calling itsfunction. Retrieve the variable missing units from the issue. Set its units to be millivolts. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Units class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Units unitAttributes False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Units?fName=unitAttributes removeUnit False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Units?fName=removeUnit addUnit False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Units?fName=addUnit - useful 3.d Choose your preferred method and use it to retrieve the problem unit attributes and print them all to the terminal. Then fix the issue. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.e Retrieve the variable either using the issue pointer method, or using the name method, and set its interface to be the required type. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.f Revalidate the model and confirm that the errors have gone. dothis Model class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Model Component class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component Tutorial functions component False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Model?fName=component (“componentName”, true) will search for the component’s name in the whole of the encapsulation hierarchy. - addComponent False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component?fName=addComponent - printEncapsulation code will output just the names of the components, nested in their encapsulation hierarchy. - useful 3.g Even though the model is free from validation errors, we still need to make sure it represents what we want it to. Print the model to the terminal and check its structure. dothis 3.h Use the addComponent functions to rearrange the components as needed until you have the required structure. Validate the model again. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle AnyItem code CellmlElementType code retrieving anstructure (whose “first” attribute is an enum of the; and “second” attribute is an std::any cast of the item itself); and casting it appropriately, or VARIABLE code Issue::variable() code since we know that the type of item in this error is a, we can call the convenience methodto return the variable which needs attention. (Of course you could retrieve it using the name of its parent component and its name too - this is just another way!) - Units code The manual way. The issue description tells us the name of thewhere the issue is, and the name of the units required by one of its children. We can locate both items using these names, remove the problem child, and replace it with a correct one. Unit code Unit code Unit code Units code The pointer way. As with the example in 3.c, we can retrieve a structure representing thechild directly from the issue. Since (as above) we know it will be aitem, we can call the issue->unit() function to retrieve it. Theitem consists of a pointer to its parentitem, and the index of the relevant child. Units code The roundabout option. Since the error is saying that units named “i_dont_exist” are missing, we could simply provide them by creating aitem and adding it to the model. arabic ) step-3-repair-the-parsed-model step\ 3:\ repair\ the\ parsed\ model Step 4: Resolve the model’s imports Importer code It’s important to remember that the imports are merely instructions for how components or units items should be located: only their syntax is checked by the validator, not that the files exist or contain the required information. To debug the imported aspects of the model, we need to use anclass. To resolve the imports, we need a path to a base location against which any relative file addresses can be resolved. For this tutorial, the files are in the same directory as the code, so simply using an empty string is sufficient. Fix the issues reported by the importer. This needs to be an iterative process because as more files become available to the importer, the content of those files needs to be checked too. To fix this, we have two options: Importer code It’s included here to highlight the fact that theclass opens and instantiates all required dependencies, and that some of those dependencies may have problems of their own … even issues in files that haven’t (yet) been seen at all by you, the user. If they’re another directory, make sure to end your path with a slash, “/”. If they’re in your working directory, enter an empty string. nb Importer class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Importer create False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Importer?fName=create resolveImports False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Importer?fName=create - useful 4.a Importer code Create aninstance and use it to resolve the model. dothis 4.b Similarly to the validator, the importer will log any issues it encounters. Retrieve these and print to the terminal (you can do this manually or using the convenience function as before). dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Component class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component setImportReference False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component?fName=setImportReference - useful 4.c We need to change the import reference for the component to be “gateEquations” instead of “i_dont_exist”. You can either retrieve the component using its name or directly from the item stored with the issue. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 4.d In this example we can change the import of the controller component to have url of ‘SodiumChannelController.cellml’. dothis 4.e Resolve the imports again and check that there are no further issues. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle to open and repair the file which is actually broken, or to switch the import source in this current model to one which doesn’t have circular imports. - step-4-resolve-the-model-s-imports step\ 4:\ resolve\ the\ model's\ imports Step 5: Validate the imported dependencies Importer code At this stage we’ve validated the local model, and we’ve used theclass to retrieve all of its import dependencies. These dependencies are stored in the importer’s library, and have not yet been validated or analysed. ImportSource code Note that the two files creating the circular import in 4.a are still in the library. To limit ourselves to only those models which are still relevant as the import dependencies of our repaired model, we can iterate through our model’sitems instead. As soon as the model’s imports have been resolved, all these will point to instantiated models within the importer. Importer class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Importer libraryCount False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Importer?fName=libraryCount returns the number of stored models; library False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Importer?fName=library returns the model at the given index or given key string; key False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Importer?fName=key returns a key string at the given index; - useful 5.a Use a simple loop to validate each of the models stored in the importer’s library. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Model class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Model ImportSource class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1ImportSource importSourceCount False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Model?fName=importSourceCount importSource False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Model?fName=importSource - model False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1ImportSource?fName=model url False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1ImportSource?fName=url - useful 5.b Loop through the model’s import source items and print their URLs to the terminal. You’ll notice that these have been used as the keys in the importer library. Check that the importer library’s models are the same as that attached to the import source item. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-5-validate-the-imported-dependencies step\ 5:\ validate\ the\ imported\ dependencies Step 6: Analyse the model(s) Analyser code Analyser code Validator code Importer code As with the validator, theclass is a diagnostic class which will check whether the mathematical representation is ready for simulation. This involves making sure that variables are contained in equations, that integrated variables have initial conditions, and that there are no over- or under-constrained sets of equations. Since this model uses imports, the real mathematical model is hidden from the(just as it was from the). The way around this is to use theclass to create a flat (ie: import-free) version of the same model. If the flat model meets the analyser’s checks, then the importing version will too. The issue returned from the analyser says that we’re trying to use two different variables as the base variable of integration, and the CellML code generation facility (which the analyser is tied to) does not support this yet. It’s still valid CellML though! In this example, the real problem is that these two variables are talking about the same thing, but haven’t been connected to one another yet. Now we see the importance of checking iteratively for issues in the analyser class. The nature of this class means that frequently it is unable to continue processing when an issue is encountered. It’s not unusual to fix one issue only to find twenty more! Two of the errors reported deal with non-initialised variables. Looking at the model printout we can see that this is because the integrated variable “X” (in both the imported gates) hasn’t been connected to its local variable “h” or “m” in the appropriate parameters component. The nice thing about issues in this class is that frequently a few issues refer to the same single problem. The remainder of the issues reported deal with variables that are not computed. This could mean any one of: Because the “is not computed” errors are cascading by nature, frequently fixing just one will resolve many others. Hints for this tutorial: Analyser class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Analyser analyseModel False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Analyser?fName=analyseModel flattenModel False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Analyser?fName=flattenModel - useful 6.a Analyser code Create aninstance and pass in the model for analysis. dothis 6.b Retrieve and print the issues from the analysis to the screen. We expect to see messages related to un-computed variables, since anything which is imported is missing from this model. dothis 6.c Create a flattened version of the model print it to the screen. Notice that any comments indicating that a component was an import have been removed as these components have been instantiated in the flattened model. dothis 6.d Analyse the flattened model and print the issues to the screen. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Variable class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Variable addEquivalence False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Variable?fName=addEquivalence - useful 6.e Create any necessary variable equivalences so that these two variables are connected. You can refer to your printout of the model’s structure to help if need be, and remember that only variables in a sibling or parent/child relationship can be connected. dothis 6.f Re-flatten and re-analyse the model and print the issues to the terminal. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 6.g Create all required connections needed to connect these variables. Re-flatten, re-analyse and print the issues to the terminal. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle printEquivalentVariableSet code C++:with the variable argument print_equivalent_variable_set code Python:with the variable argument - useful 6.h From the printout of your model and the issues listed, determine what needs to happen in order to make the model viable, and do it. Check that your final analysis contains no issues. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle the variable is not included in any equations (it’s completely unused); the variable is included in an equation, but the equation can’t be evaluated (contains some other un-computed variable(s)); the variable is a constant that should have a value assigned; or the variable hasn’t been connected to the rest of its definition (usually it’s this one!). arabic ) There is at least one of each kind of problem; There’s a convenience function provided (see below) which will print the equivalent variable set for a given variable. You can use the item stored by each issue and this function to check for missing connections. addEquivalence code thefunction returns a boolean indicating success or otherwise. If you check this as you go it will alert you quickly if you’re trying to connect to a variable that’s not found. - step-6-analyse-the-model-s step\ 6:\ analyse\ the\ model(s) Step 7: Serialise and print the repaired model 7.a Printer code Create ainstance and use it to print the CellML-formatted version of the repaired model to a string. Remember we’ll still be printing the original version of the model, not the flattened one! dothis 7.b Tutorial 4 std std-ref True ../hh_tutorial4/index#generatemembranemodel Write the string to a file named “SodiumChannelModel.cellml”; you will use this in. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-7-serialise-and-print-the-repaired-model step\ 7:\ serialise\ and\ print\ the\ repaired\ model hodgkin-huxley-3-debugging-a-model debugsodiumchannelmodel hodgkin-huxley\ 3:\ debugging\ a\ model debugsodiumchannelmodel /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/tutorials-tested-docs/hh_tutorial3/index.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Hodgkin-Huxley 2: Creating a model which uses imports
content: createpotassiumchannelmodel Hodgkin-Huxley 2: Creating a model which uses imports By the time you have worked through this tutorial you will be able to: Assemble a multi-component model using the API; Create a model which imports items from others; Inter-connect the components using the equivalent variables functionality; Validator code Use the diagnosticclass to identify errors in the model’s syntax; Analyser code Use the diagnosticclass to identify errors in the model’s mathematical formulation; and Serialise the model to CellML format for output. - shortlist C++ resources Python resources CellML resources CMakeLists.txt xref download ccea8178b5cdde1efc3a12050e071449/CMakeLists.txt hh_tutorial2/index True CMakeLists.txt download False The CMake file for building this tutorial; When a problem is found, anitem is created containing: We can use these issues as we need to. The simplest way is to print the descriptions to the terminal. step-2-create-a-potassium-channel-equations-component step\ 2:\ create\ a\ potassium\ channel\ equations\ component Step 3: Create the nGate and its child components The nGateEquations has some of the working of a generic gate (which we’ll import from GateModel.cellml), but instead of constant values for alpha and beta, we’ll introduce a voltage dependence. The nGateParameters component allows us to specify those parameters specific to the movement of potassium. 3.a Create a component, name it “nGate”, and add it to the equations component. dothis 3.b Create a component, name it “nGateEquations” and add it to the nGate component. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.c Add the mathematics to the nGateEquations component and validate the model. The only two which aren’t available are: Remember that you’ll need to give these names that are the same as those needed by the variables. In this case they are “per_ms” and “per_mV_ms”. per millisecond; and per millivolt millisecond. - dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 3.f Associate the correct units items with the variables which need them. Revalidate the model, expecting there to be no errors reported. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-3-create-the-ngate-and-its-child-components step\ 3:\ create\ the\ ngate\ and\ its\ child\ components Step 4: Specify imports for the generic gate components The generic gate model (in GateModel.cellml) has two components: We will import only the “gateEquations” component and set it to be a child of the nGateEquations component. This means we can introduce the voltage dependence for the alpha and beta, and using a specified initial value for the gate’s status. Note that the variable “n” in the nGateEquations is equivalent to the generic gate’s variable “X”. Imports require three things: Note that we are deliberately not importing the parameters component in the GateModel.cellml file, since we will be setting our own values of its variables. “gateEquations” which solves an ODE for the gate status parameter, X; and “gateParameters” which sets the values of alpha, beta, and initialises X. - container::shortlist preserve Component code Units code A destination for the imported item. This should be at the top of the encapsulation hierarchy, and should import the component named “controller” from the file “PotassiumChannelController.cellml”. Validator code Analyser code At this point we’ve defined the equations that govern the potassium channel’s operation. We’ve also confirmed that the CellML representation of these equations is valid (using the); now we need to check that it’s also solvable (using the). 5.a Repeat steps 4.a-d for the controller component. Put it at the top level of the encapsulation hierarchy. dothis 5.b Validate the model and confirm that there are no issues. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-5-specify-imports-for-the-controller-component step\ 5:\ specify\ imports\ for\ the\ controller\ component Step 6: Analyse the model Analyser code Validator code We will introduce theclass here so that its use as a debugging tool can be demonstrated. Of course, we know ahead of time that there is still a lot of connections to be created between the components, but the analyser can help us to find them. The analyser is similar to theclass and keeps a record of issues it encounters. Even though all of the messages we see are “variable not calculated” errors, we can divide them into different categories: A reminder: printModel(Model, bool) code code We’re aiming for a potassium channel component which can accept two external parameters - time, t (ms) and voltage, V (mV) - and use them to calculate a potassium current, i_K (microA_per_cm2). A utility functionhas been provided to help you to see what’s going on inside your model. Setting the second optional parameter towill also print the MathML content. nb 6.a Analyser code analyseModel code Create anitem and pass it the model for checking using itsfunction. dothis 6.b Retrieve the analyser’s issues and print them to the terminal, just as you’ve done for the validator. Expect messages related to un-computed variables. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle those variables which are constants whose value has not been set yet; those variables whose calculation depends on as-yet un-calculated variables; those variables which need to be connected to where their calculation happens; and those variables which aren’t present in any equation. - step-6-analyse-the-model step\ 6:\ analyse\ the\ model Step 7: Define the constants As we work through the next few steps we’ll be defining and connecting all of the components and variables together. First we’ll define the variables which will have a constant value in the simulation. Create parameters siblings components for the equations components, and add the variables that they will require. These are: You can either do this by creating the variables from scratch (as in Step 3.d) but because these are intended to be duplicates of existing variables, but in another component, we can simply add a cloned variable to the parameters component. If we were to analyse the model again now we would we still have the same set of errors as earlier as we haven’t given a value to any of our parameters. 7.a Use the print model helper function to show your current model contents. This should show that we have currently got variables only in the nGateEquations and potassiumChannelEquations components. These need to have sibling parameters components created to hold any hard-coded values or initial conditions that are required. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 7.b Create parameters components for the equations components, and add cloned versions of any variables which need to be given a value into the new parameters components. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 7.c In order for other encapsulating components to access these variables, they also need to have intermediate variables in the nGate or potassium channel components too. This is only true of variables that you want to be available to the outside. In this example, we need to add the variable “n” to the nGate in order that its parent (the potassium channel equations) can access it. dothis 7.d Create variable connections between these variables and their counterparts in the equations components. Validate, expecting errors related to missing or incorrect interface types. dothis 7.e setInterfaceType code fixVariableInterfaces code Set the required interface types as listed by the validator. This can be done individually using thefunction on each variable, or automatically using thefunction on the entire model. Validate again, expecting no validation errors. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle These values should be: Potassium channel parameters: E_K = -85 [mV] g_K = 36 [milliS_per_cm2] - nGate parameters: n = 0.325 [dimensionless] - - shortlist 7.f setInitialValue code Use thefunction to set these parameter values. Analyse the model again, expecting that the calculation errors related to these constants have been solved. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle potassium channel parameters E_K (-87) g_K (36) - nGate parameters initial value for n (dimensionless) - - step-7-define-the-constants step\ 7:\ define\ the\ constants Step 8: Connect the input variables Looking at the variables listed in the issues above we can see that some of our “external” or “input” variables are listed more than once. These are the voltage, V, and time, t. Time is needed in every equations component, including the imported gate component. Voltage is needed by the potassium channel and nGate equations components. Connections between the variables in any two components are only possible when those components are in a sibling-sibling or parent-child relationship. We can see from the printed structure that the top-level potassium channel component doesn’t have any variables, and neither does the nGate component. We’ll need to create intermediate variables in those components to allow connections to be made through them. 8.a Print the model to the terminal and notice the components which contain V and t variables. dothis 8.b Create dummy variables for time and voltage using the cloning technique described in Step 7.b, and add a clone to each appropriate component. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 8.c Connect these variables to their counterparts as needed. dothis 8.d Fix the variable interfaces and validate the model, expecting no errors. dothis 8.e Analyse the model and expect that errors related to voltage and time now occur only in the top-level potassium channel component. Because this needs to be connected to the imported controller component, they’ll be addressed later in Step 10. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-8-connect-the-input-variables step\ 8:\ connect\ the\ input\ variables Step 9: Connect the calculated variables Now we need to make sure that all of the calculated variables can move through the model properly. In this example, the only calculated variable is n, the gate status. This is calculated by solving the ODE in the nGate equations component, but needs to be initialised by the nGate parameters component, and its value passed back to the potassium channel equations component. 9.a Make the required variable connections as described above. dothis 9.b Fix the variable interfaces for the model, and validate, expecting no errors. dothis 9.c Analyse the model, expecting that the errors related to the n variable have been resolved. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-9-connect-the-calculated-variables step\ 9:\ connect\ the\ calculated\ variables Step 10: Connect to imported components At this point, we have made all the connections we can between existing variables and components. (You can verify this for yourself by printing your model to the terminal again if you like.) Now the problem we have is that we need to connect to variables inside imported components, but these don’t exist in our model yet: the import sources that we created in Steps 4 and 5 are simply a recipe; they don’t actually create anything here. Importer code In order to connect to variables in imported components, we can create dummy variables inside them. These will be overwritten when the imports are resolved and the model flattened, at which time the imported variables will replace the dummy ones. As with other steps, we have a choice here. We can manually create variables or clone existing ones into the destination components we have already created; or we can make use of theclass to help us manage these. We’re going to do the latter now. hasUnresolvedImports code Resolving the imports in a model triggers the importer to go searching for all of the information required by this model’s imports, even through multiple generations of import layers. It also instantiates each of those requirements into its own library. You could use the model’sfunction to test whether the operation was successful or not; expecting it to be true before resolution, and false afterwards. Importer code Validator code Theclass has a logger (just like the), so needs to be checked for issues. The models which have the source components that we wanted to reuse from the GateModel.cellml and PotassiumChannelController.cellml files are now available to us in two ways: Analyser code Theclass can only operate on a flat (ie: import-free) model. In order to do the final check before serialising our model for output, we will use the importer to create a flattened version of the model to submit for analysis. 10.a Importer code Create anitem. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 10.b resolveImports code Pass the model and the path to the GateModel.cellml file into the importer’sfunction. dothis 10.c Check for issues and print any found to the terminal - we do not expect any at this stage. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 10.d libraryCount code key(index) code Iterate through the items in the library (will give you the total), and print its keys to the terminal. The keys can be retrieved as a string from thefunction. This should contain two models. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 10.e We can simply use a clone of the imported components to define dummy variables in the destination component. Create dummy components from the resolved imported components. You can get these from the library or from the import source’s model (or one of each, to prove to yourself that it works either way!). dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle GOTCHA: Note that when an item is added to a new parent, it is automatically removed from its original parent. Iterating through a set of children is best done in descending index order or using a while loop so that child items are not skipped as the indices change. nb 10.f Iterate through the variables in each dummy component, and add a clone of each variable to the destination component. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 10.g Connect all the variables in the nGate equations component to the dummy variables in the imported gate component. These connections should be: Repeat for the controller component and the potassium channel component. Fix the variable interfaces and validate the model, expecting there to be no errors. nGate equations component : imported gate component n : X alpha_n : alpha_X beta_n : beta_X t : t - dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 10.h Make sure that the output variable from this component - the potassium current - is available at the top level, and with a public and private interface. You’ll need to create a dummy variable in the potassium channel component and link it appropriately. Validate your model and expect no errors. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 10.i Create a flat version of the model and submit it for analysis. Print the errors dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Note that at this point an analysis of the unflattened model will still show errors, but that’s totally fine. nb model code ImportSource code through thefunction of the destination component’sitem; or as an item in the importer’s library. The library items can be retrieved either by index or by key, where the key is the name of the file that was resolved. - step-10-connect-to-imported-components step\ 10:\ connect\ to\ imported\ components Step 11: Output the model 11.a Printer code Tutorial 4 std std-ref True ../hh_tutorial4/index#generatemembranemodel Create ainstance and use it to serialise the model. This creates a string containing the CellML-formatted version of the model. Write this to a file called “PotassiumChannelModel.cellml”; you will need this in. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-11-output-the-model step\ 11:\ output\ the\ model hodgkin-huxley-2-creating-a-model-which-uses-imports createpotassiumchannelmodel hodgkin-huxley\ 2:\ creating\ a\ model\ which\ uses\ imports createpotassiumchannelmodel /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/tutorials-tested-docs/hh_tutorial2/index.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Hodgkin-Huxley 1: Creating a model using the API
content: creategatemodel Hodgkin-Huxley 1: Creating a model using the API By the time you have worked through this tutorial you will be able to: Assemble a model using the API; Use the diagnostic Validator class to identify errors in the model’s syntax; Use the diagnostic Analyser class to identify errors in the model’s mathematical construction; and Serialise the model to CellML format for output. - shortlist C++ resources Python resources CMakeLists.txt xref download fbc14854c947b600f7f3fc207b2ae5a6/CMakeLists.txt hh_tutorial1/index True CMakeLists.txt download False The CMake file for building this tutorial; createGateModel.cpp xref download 91c4144be2a2f6a9af996896f159163f/createGateModel.cpp hh_tutorial1/index True createGateModel.cpp download False Either the skeleton code, or .. createGateModel_complete.cpp xref download ceabe07f7ea0de1d6a3afd430c503162/createGateModel_complete.cpp hh_tutorial1/index True createGateModel_complete.cpp download False the completed tutorial code; and utilities.cpp xref download 0ce19d601e38791d06861735a2cc883a/utilities.cpp hh_tutorial1/index True /resources/code/utilities/utilities.cpp download False utilities.h xref download 671589e0c1b0eb2849b65b2f33b85d90/utilities.h hh_tutorial1/index True /resources/code/utilities/utilities.h download False andHelper functions. - createGateModel.py xref download cc36383abfbbd9757631f77686258331/createGateModel.py hh_tutorial1/index True createGateModel.py download False Either the skeleton code, or .. createGateModel_complete.py xref download 31c1066d034ab5d06ffcb4eea4715fec/createGateModel_complete.py hh_tutorial1/index True createGateModel_complete.py download False the completed tutorial code. - directorylist Overview Ion Gate theory page False /documentation/theory/ion_gates This is the first tutorial in a series designed to walk the user through some of libCellML’s functionality available in the API. Its goal is to create from scratch a voltage-independent ion gate model. The theory of this kind of gate can be found on the. One of the goals of the CellML format (which must be supported by libCellML) is the construction of models that are reusable. Throughout these tutorials we will create entities in such a way as to enable their reuse as easily as possible. The basic structure of this model highlights that too. This arrangement means that it’s simple to import this model into others, as well as to locate or over-ride parameter values or reuse equations. Each of the components created throughout this series of tutorials will follow this same structure. We will create a model with three components: equations Ancomponent, which contains all of the working pieces and mathematics specific to the model; parameters Acomponent, which contains any hard-coded parameters or values specific to this model; and wrapper Acomponent, which is the parent of the other two. - shortlist overview overview Step 1: Set up the model Model class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Model Component class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component create False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Model?fName=create setName False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Model?fName=setName addComponent False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Model?fName=addComponent - create False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component?fName=create setName False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component?fName=setName addComponent False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component?fName=addComponent - useful 1.a Model code create code The first step is to create aitem which will later contain the component and the units it needs. Use thefunction to make a new instance. dothis 1.b setName code Each CellML element must have a name, which is set using thefunction. Set the name of the model to be “GateModel”. dothis 1.c Component code Create a newitem named “gate” using the overloaded constructor. dothis 1.d addComponent code Add the component to the model using thefunction. dothis printModel(Model, bool) code print_model code code A utility function(C++) or(Python) has been provided to help you to see what’s going on inside your model. Setting the second optional parameter towill also print the MathML content. useful 1.e Print your model to the terminal and check that the structure is what you’d expect. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle We’ll create a wrapper component whose only job is to encapsulate the other components. This makes is a lot easier for this model to be reused, as the connections between components internal to this one won’t need to be re-established. Note that the constructor for all named CellML entities is overloaded, so you can pass it the name string at the time of creation. Finally we need to add the component to the model. This sets it at the top-level of the component encapsulation hierarchy. All other components will then need to be added to this component, rather than to the model. step-1-set-up-the-model step\ 1:\ set\ up\ the\ model Step 2: Create the gateEquations component Inside the wrapper component you created in Step 1 we need to create two more: an equations component, and a parameters component. In this step we’ll construct the equations component. equations Since this is an-flavoured component, it should contain the bulk of the calculations and mathematics for the gate. Maths is added using MathML2 (no other levels are supported) strings. In this example we need to represent just one equation: If you’re happy to write your own MathML2 string then please go ahead, but if you’d rather not you can use the code provided under the code toggles further down the page. 2.a Create a new equations component named “gateEquations”. dothis 2.b Add the new gateEquations component to the gate component. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Component class False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component setMath False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component?fName=setMath appendMath False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component?fName=appendMath math False /documentation/v0.6.3/api/classlibcellml_1_1Component?fName=math - useful 2.c setMath code appendMath code Construct a string representing the MathML of the equation above. You will need to enclose the string with the appropriate header and footer. These are provided for you in the skeleton code, or simply copy them from below. Use theandfunctions to add your strings to the equations component. dothis 2.d code Print the model to the terminal and include the optional second argument ofto include the MathML. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle \frac{dX}{dt} = \alpha_{X}\left( 1 - X \right) - \beta_{X}.X hh_tutorial1/index True False True preserve step-2-create-the-gateequations-component step\ 2:\ create\ the\ gateequations\ component Step 3: Validate the model Validator code Once the mathematics has been added to the component, and the component to the model, we can make use of the diagnostic messages within theclass to tell us what else needs to be done. Calling the validator does not return anything: we have to go looking for issues that it found during processing. We can use these issues as we need to. The simplest way is to print the descriptions to the terminal. These are: C++ Python getIssueLevelFromEnum code . - get_issue_level_from_enum code . - shortlist useful 3.b issueCount code issue(index) code Retrieve the number of issues encountered using thefunction on the validator, then retrieve the issue items from the validator using their index and thefunction. Print the information from each issue to the terminal. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-3-validate-the-model step\ 3:\ validate\ the\ model Step 4: Add the variables The issues reported by the validator are related to the MathML string that we entered in Step 2 requiring variables which don’t yet exist. These must be created, named, and added to their parent component. Add these missing variables to the equations component. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Helper functions for retrieving and printing any issues from any of the logger classes: printIssues code (C++) print_issues code (Python) - useful 4.b printIssues code Validate the model again. Note that you can use the helper functionwith the validator as the argument to save repeating the code from 3.b each time. Expect errors relating to missing units. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-4-add-the-variables step\ 4:\ add\ the\ variables Step 5: Add the units The validator has reported that the four variables are missing units attributes. Understanding units False /documentation/v0.6.3/aside/understanding_units Units code Some basic units have been defined and built into libCellML, others you can define by combining the built-in ones using scaling factors and exponents, or you can define your own from scratch if need be. Please read thepage for more detailed information, but for now let’s look at a simple example that defines aitem representing millivolts. This can either be done individually using thefunction on each variable, or en masse for all the model’s variable interfaces using itsfunction. Validate and analyse again, expecting no errors. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle In order to avoid hard-coding values here, we will need to connect to external values to initialise the “X” variable and provide the value for “alpha_X” and “beta_X”. parameters This is the reason for the second internal component, thecomponent. Understanding collections of items False /documentation/v0.6.3/aside/understanding_collections So far in this tutorial we’ve only been creating items, defining them, and adding to their parent items. Now for the first time we will need to retrieve a child item from its parent. This can be done in one of two ways: either by the child’s index or by its name. There is more information about interacting with collections of items on thepage. Two particularly useful idioms are shown below. step-6-analyse-the-mathematical-construction-of-the-model step\ 6:\ analyse\ the\ mathematical\ construction\ of\ the\ model Step 7: Sanity check printModel(Model, bool) code print_model code Model code There’s a helper function provided for these tutorials which will print the model to the terminal. Use(in C++) or(in Python) function to print the contents of the given. The second (optional) argument indicates whether or not to print the MathML strings in the components too. useful 7.a Print the model to the terminal using the helper function. dothis 7.b Create intermediate variables for time, t and gate status, X in the gate component, and ensure they have a public and private interface to enable two-way connection. You will also need to set a public and private connection onto t and X in the equations component too, or repeat the call to fix the model’s interfaces as in step 6.f. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle 7.c Connect the intermediate variables to their respective partners in the equations component, and recheck the model. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle Looking at the printout we see that the top-level component named “gate” has no variables. Even though this is clearly a valid situation (as proved by 6.f), it’s not going to make this model easy to reuse. We need to make sure that any input and output variables are also connected into the top-level gate component. step-7-sanity-check step\ 7:\ sanity\ check Step 8: Serialise and output the model Printer code Model code Theclass in libCellML takes the stored instance of aitem and creates a string representing its serialisation into CellML code. 8.a Printer code Create ainstance and use it to serialise the model into a string. Write this string to a file called “GateModel.cellml”. dothis Show C++ snippet header toggle Show Python snippet header toggle step-8-serialise-and-output-the-model step\ 8:\ serialise\ and\ output\ the\ model hodgkin-huxley-1-creating-a-model-using-the-api creategatemodel hodgkin-huxley\ 1:\ creating\ a\ model\ using\ the\ api creategatemodel /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/tutorials-tested-docs/hh_tutorial1/index.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Simulation tool developer: Solver
content: users-solver Simulation tool developer: Solver The code generation functionality in libCellML can be used to transform CellML models into procedural code for simulation. This example works through that process. C++ resources : Python resources : CMakeLists.txt xref download c3875bfa0c2a1f1d593bc10fb1635cbf/CMakeLists.txt common_use_cases/solver True /resources/code/solver/CMakeLists.txt download False example_solveGeneratedModel.cpp xref download bcee499fcda27579ee11394c8ddb8c88/solveGeneratedModel.cpp common_use_cases/solver True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.cpp download False resources/ sineComparisonExample.c xref download 7ab90524c466b0803124f74c76123814/sineComparisonExample.c common_use_cases/solver True /resources/code/generated_code/sineComparisonExample.c download False sineComparisonExample.h xref download ad864591c6eaed1a7e848a276e880cd7/sineComparisonExample.h common_use_cases/solver True /resources/code/generated_code/sineComparisonExample.h download False - - example_solveGeneratedModel.py xref download 720f0969a3d62e612fd4909324baa756/solveGeneratedModel.py common_use_cases/solver True /resources/code/solver/solveGeneratedModel.py download False resources/ sineComparisonExample.py xref download f7de50c71829e0052e372d2987e907e1/sineComparisonExample.py common_use_cases/solver True /resources/code/generated_code/sineComparisonExample.py download False - - directorylist Create a placeholder for the solver Interacting with procedural code means that we need a program, so the first step is to create what will soon become our solver. To start with, the program only reads and interprets command line arguments; the size and number of timesteps to simulate. This is done using a simple function, as below. Once the function exists, we can call it from the main function to process the command line arguments. For Python, the generated code must be converted into a module, and then imported. This is shown in the example code below. *.h code *.c code -DINPUT=yourBaseFileName code .h code modelToSolve.cpp code modelToSolve.h code #include code For C it’s a little more complicated, as you will need to compile the solver whilst including the generated interfacefile and linking to the implementationfile. A CMake file is provided which will do this for you. The build process needs to know the name of the implementation file containing the generated code, so this is given as theargument (without extension). This file and the corresponding interfacefile are copied by CMake to two files namedandrespectively. This step is required so that within the solver code we cana known file name. C building and linking panel-2-2-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-2-2-0 2-0 tab 0 Python panel-2-2-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-2-2-1 2-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist sineComparisonExample.[c,h] code Navigate into the folder containing the generated codeas well as the :code:` example_solveGeneratedModel.cpp` source code from above. You should see an output similar to this: solve_ code -DINPUT code Note that the combined program is now available with the prefixbefore the base file name you provided with theargument, and can be run using the instructions given in the printout above. tab-2-2-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-2-2-0 2-0 tabpanel 0 tab-2-2-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-2-2-1 2-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element connect-with-the-generated-code connect\ with\ the\ generated\ code Retrieve the generated model information The generated code contains model information in dictionaries, as well as functions to interface with the model’s mathematics. These are: VOI_INFO code .name code .units code .component code : a dictionary with the,, andattributes related to the variable of integration, STATE_INFO code : a list of similar information for the state variables, VARIABLE_INFO code : a list of similar information for the non-state variables. - C++ panel-3-3-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-3-3-0 3-0 tab 0 Python panel-3-3-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-3-3-1 3-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-3-3-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-3-3-0 3-0 tabpanel 0 tab-3-3-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-3-3-1 3-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element retrieve-the-generated-model-information retrieve\ the\ generated\ model\ information Allocate space for the solution Also within the generated code are functions to allocate space for the variables: create states array: to construct arrays for storage of the state variables and their rates; create variables array: to construct an array to store the other variables. - C++ panel-4-4-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-4-4-0 4-0 tab 0 Python panel-4-4-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-4-4-1 4-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-4-4-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-4-4-0 4-0 tabpanel 0 tab-4-4-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-4-4-1 4-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element allocate-space-for-the-solution allocate\ space\ for\ the\ solution Retrieve the model’s mathematical formulation The mathematical equations that govern the model’s behaviour can be applied using functions from within the generated code: compute rates compute variables Note that all model variables which affect the rates’ values (and thereby affect the states’ values) are updated in thefunction. This means that you only need to call thefunction when you’re saving the output from a step; it does not need to be called for intermediate timesteps. Before we begin iterating, the values of all variables are calculated. initialise states and constants: does what it says, sets all the initial value attributes; compute computed constants: computes the value of any constants which depend on others; compute variables: calculates those variables whose values depend on the state variables; and compute rates: calculates the rates of change of the state variables. - C++ panel-5-5-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-5-5-0 5-0 tab 0 Python panel-5-5-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-5-5-1 5-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-5-5-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-5-5-0 5-0 tabpanel 0 tab-5-5-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-5-5-1 5-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element retrieve-the-model-s-mathematical-formulation retrieve\ the\ model's\ mathematical\ formulation Prepare a file for the solution output If you have an alternative way to save your solution, you can skip this step. Here we create a simple text-delimited file into which the solution can be written at each timestep. C++ panel-6-6-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-6-6-0 6-0 tab 0 Python panel-6-6-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-6-6-1 6-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-6-6-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-6-6-0 6-0 tabpanel 0 tab-6-6-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-6-6-1 6-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element prepare-a-file-for-the-solution-output prepare\ a\ file\ for\ the\ solution\ output Perform the integration steps Finally we iterate through the timesteps, calculating the state variables, and updating the rates each step. The solution values and calculated variables are written to the output file. The solution files are written in a tab-delimited format which can be read by your favourite plotting application. The plots below were generated using a step size of 0.1 for 100 iterations. The import statements are basically a recipe for how these imported items can be combined to make the present model. While models which contain import dependencies are perfectly valid, they cannot be used to generate runnable code. The process of resolving the imports (telling libCellML where to look for these ingredients) and flattening the model (creating instances of the ingredients and removing the dependency) is necessary before code generation can happen. Importer code Theclass supports all functionality to do with imports, and contains its own logger which can be used to report anything that might have gone wrong. snippet-importer-resolve C++ panel-1-1-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-0 1-0 tab 0 Python panel-1-1-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-1 1-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist example_simulationToolDev.cpp xref download 89c84d26a969eb1182bbdc7a0ffbaf8a/simulationToolDev.cpp common_use_cases/simulation_tool_dev True /resources/code/simulation_tool_dev/simulationToolDev.cpp download False Full context: tab-1-1-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-1-1-0 1-0 tabpanel 0 example_simulationToolDev.py xref download b302646fbd7722934aed90a32900e1e2/simulationToolDev.py common_use_cases/simulation_tool_dev True /resources/code/simulation_tool_dev/simulationToolDev.py download False Full context: tab-1-1-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-1-1-1 1-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs snippet-importer-resolve snippet_importer_resolve tab-element resolve-imports-and-flatten-model resolve\ imports\ and\ flatten\ model Validate model Validator code Theis the equivalent of a spelling checker: it can check that each item in a model has all of the information it needs, but it can’t check whether it means what you intend it to. Thus even if a model is valid, it could still be the equivalent of correctly-spelled nonsense. Validator code ERROR code CellML normative specification False https://cellml-specification.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ Once a model has been passed to ainstance, the validator’s internal logger will contain a list of any of the issues which have been encountered during the checking process. A model can be said to be valid - that is, conforming to the- if the validator’s logger contains no issues with a level of. title: Model debugger
content: users-model-debugger Model debugger Validator code Analyser code This example walks through the process of using theandclasses to check a CellML model’s syntax and mathematical composition. The CellML file used in this example makes use of imports, so we need to have the main file (debugAnalysisExample.cellml) as well as the file which it imports (debugAnalysisExampleImport.cellml). This example shows a model which has imports, so we need to resolve these and flatten the model before any analysis can happen. For detailed information on debugging models with imports, please see theexamples. C++ snippet panel-1-1-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-0 1-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-1-1-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-1 1-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-1-1-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-1-1-0 1-0 tabpanel 0 tab-1-1-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-1-1-1 1-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element resolve-the-imports-and-flatten-the-model resolve\ the\ imports\ and\ flatten\ the\ model Validate the model Validator code Analyser code Theclass process is like a spelling checker: it will check the syntax of the model ahead of analysing its mathematical formulation in thelater. Here we create a validator, use it to check the model, and retrieve the descriptions of any issues it found. The validation issues raised can be used to fix any “spelling” problems with the model. It will check for errors of logic or mathematical definition in the model formulation, and also make sure that all of the information which a solver needs is available. Theworks in the same way as the other service classes: we create an instance, pass a model for checking, and then retrieve any issues it may have found. C++ panel-0-0-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-0 0-0 tab 0 Python panel-0-0-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-0-0-1 0-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-0-0-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-0-0-0 0-0 tabpanel 0 tab-0-0-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-0-0-1 0-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element parse-an-existing-cellml-model parse\ an\ existing\ cellml\ model Create an Importer and resolve the model’s imports Importer code Importer code Importer code Theclass is a utility which can be used to handle models which import components or units from other models. Passing the model and a base directory location will enable theto resolve any imports required by the model, and add those dependencies to the importer’s internal library. Since theclass contains a logger, we can check that the process has completed properly by printing any issues inside the importer to the terminal. The code above prints to the terminal: C++ panel-1-1-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-0 1-0 tab 0 Python panel-1-1-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-1-1-1 1-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-1-1-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-1-1-0 1-0 tabpanel 0 tab-1-1-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-1-1-1 1-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element create-an-importer-and-resolve-the-model-s-imports create\ an\ importer\ and\ resolve\ the\ model's\ imports Validate and analyse the model Validator code Analyser code The analysis tools - theand- will read only the highest level of the model they are given; they do not look into any of the imported items, so they can’t check them. In order to retain the import structure but be able to use the diagnostic tools, we can create a flattened copy of the model for testing. This can be used to identify mistakes in the original version of the model. C++ panel-2-2-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-2-2-0 2-0 tab 0 Python panel-2-2-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-2-2-1 2-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-2-2-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-2-2-0 2-0 tabpanel 0 tab-2-2-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-2-2-1 2-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element validate-and-analyse-the-model validate\ and\ analyse\ the\ model Validate the import dependencies Validator code Analyser code Importer code The issues reported by theanditems in the previous step have been hidden from the original model, as they exist somewhere in its hierarchy of imported items. We can make use of the library of import dependencies which is stored in theclass to locate the specific models in which the issues occurred, and repair them. The code above will print the following to the terminal: C++ panel-3-3-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-3-3-0 3-0 tab 0 Python panel-3-3-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-3-3-1 3-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-3-3-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-3-3-0 3-0 tabpanel 0 tab-3-3-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-3-3-1 3-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element validate-the-import-dependencies validate\ the\ import\ dependencies Fix the errors in the imported model Importer code Now that we’ve found where the error is (a variable named “iNeedUnits” within a component which is imported from a file at URL “resources/importExample3.cellml”), it’s now time to fix it. This could be done by parsing that file directly and amending it as needed, but since we already have a copy of this model inside theclass, it’s better to use that one. When the importer resolves imports, any dependencies it needs are instantiated inside its library. These models can be accessed within the library by their key (the URL from which they were read) or by their index. Here we print the list of the importer’s library keys to demonstrate, and then retrieve the model containing the error so it can be fixed. Importer code Importer code Note that altering a model instance returned from thechanges the model instance which is used to resolve the original model’s dependencies. Thechecks its own library first before opening and parsing external files, so once we’ve fixed the error in the library’s model, re-flattening the original model uses the fixed version too. nb C++ panel-4-4-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-4-4-0 4-0 tab 0 Python panel-4-4-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-4-4-1 4-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-4-4-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-4-4-0 4-0 tabpanel 0 tab-4-4-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-4-4-1 4-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element fix-the-errors-in-the-imported-model fix\ the\ errors\ in\ the\ imported\ model Analyse the import dependencies Analyser code Validator code This step repeats the two previous steps but uses theclass instead of theclass to report on issues. We can then fix the issues found in the same way, by accessing the library’s version of the imported model and repairing the problem there. C++ panel-5-5-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-5-5-0 5-0 tab 0 Python panel-5-5-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-5-5-1 5-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-5-5-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-5-5-0 5-0 tabpanel 0 tab-5-5-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-5-5-1 5-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element analyse-the-import-dependencies analyse\ the\ import\ dependencies Output the repaired models to CellML files The final step in this process is to output the repaired models to CellML files. The ability to use imports to combine model items is useful, so we want to retain that in the fixed models. For this reason, we will write all of the files involved - whether altered or not - to a new directory. By doing this, we maintain the same relationship between the model files as was there in the beginning. repaired/resources code For this example you will need to have created a directory structure ahead of time since the functions used here do not create those directories. You will need to create two nested directories:within your working directory before continuing. nb C++ panel-6-6-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-6-6-0 6-0 tab 0 Python panel-6-6-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-6-6-1 6-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-6-6-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-6-6-0 6-0 tabpanel 0 tab-6-6-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-6-6-1 6-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element output-the-repaired-models-to-cellml-files output\ the\ repaired\ models\ to\ cellml\ files import-debugger users-import-debugger import\ debugger users_import_debugger /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/tutorials-tested-docs/common_use_cases/import_debugger.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

title: Annotation tool developer
content: users-annotation-tool-dev Annotation tool developer Annotator code Annotator code std::any type False https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/any This example walks through the processes involved in preparing a CellML model for annotation. Any item in the model which requires annotation needs to have a unique ID string, so the chief business of theclass is working with the id attributes. In all other parts of libCellML, items are retrieved from their parents using either their index or their name. In the, the ID string is used instead. Because an item of any type could have an ID attribute, there is no way of knowing what kind of will be returned. The class makes use of casting to and from the (C++ only)to handle this uncertainty. Here we use theclass to read the file, and deserialise the CellML into aobject. It can be used to retrieve the ID string and item type to which it pertains, using thefunction. A null pointer will be returned if the item does not have the type requested, or if its ID does not exist in the model. C++ snippet panel-2-2-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-2-2-0 2-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-2-2-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-2-2-1 2-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-2-2-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-2-2-0 2-0 tabpanel 0 tab-2-2-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-2-2-1 2-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element retrieve-items-by-id-known-type retrieve\ items\ by\ id\ (known\ type) Retrieve items by id (unknown type) item CellMLElements code std::any type False https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/any It’s more likely that you won’t know the type of item to which a given ID relates, so will need to use the genericfunction to retrieve it. This returns two pieces of information: the first is the appropriateenum value for the type, and the second is the item itself cast into the(in C++). In Python, the returned item requires no further transformation. C++ snippet panel-3-3-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-3-3-0 3-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-3-3-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-3-3-1 3-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-3-3-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-3-3-0 3-0 tabpanel 0 tab-3-3-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-3-3-1 3-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element handle-duplicated-id-attributes retrieve-items-by-id-unknown-type retrieve\ items\ by\ id\ (unknown\ type) Handle duplicated ID attributes items Duplicated IDs in any XML document are not permitted, and CellML is no different. There are several tools to support users in removing duplicates from their models. The code snippet below uses the annotator to return a set of ID strings which have been duplicated within the model scope, and then uses the collective and generic functionto return all of them. From here, the items can be assigned an automatically generated ID string which is guaranteed to be unique within the model scope. Of course, you can also set the id of these items manually too if you’d rather. C++ snippet panel-4-4-0 true sphinx-tabs-tab tab-4-4-0 4-0 tab 0 Python snippet panel-4-4-1 false sphinx-tabs-tab tab-4-4-1 4-1 tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-4-4-0 sphinx-tabs-panel panel-4-4-0 4-0 tabpanel 0 tab-4-4-1 sphinx-tabs-panel true panel-4-4-1 4-1 tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element handle-duplicated-id-attributes id1 handle\ duplicated\ id\ attributes handle_duplicated_id_attributes Automatically assign unique IDs in bulk assignIds assignAllIds clearAllIds CellmlElementType COMPONENT code component2 code In addition to using the automatic ID generation on individual items as shown above, you can also use it for all items of a certain type. The example below shows how calling thefunction for thetype fills in the missing ID fromwithout changing the IDs of the other components. Finally, IDs for every item in a model can be set with thefunction, and cleared from every item using thefunction. title: Run-time codes
content: runtime-codes Run-time codes Logger code Many of the classes in libCellML inherit aclass, which keeps track of things that may have gone wrong, as well as giving hints when the behaviour may not be as expected. This page keeps a list of the codes that are not related to CellML syntactic validation. If you’re seeing an issue with this code, it’s because you need to use thefunction to add it. Annotator code Model code This code is generated when theis given a null pointer instead of aitem. Model code Annotator code When thethat was submitted to thisdoes not have any item with the requested id string, a warning with this code is created. Annotator code While theis able to retrieve and manipulate collections of items with the same id, any XML document with duplicated ids is not valid. When non-unique id strings are encountered, a warning with this code is created. Annotator code AnyItem code AnyItem code CellmlElementType code In contrast to all other classes in libCellML, themust be agnostic as to the type of item it deals with. It usestype in order to be able to return items without specifying their type ahead of time. An error is issued when the information stored in anitem (theof the item, and the item itself) are not consistent. Annotator code AnyItem code CellmlElementType code This issue is raised when attempting to use the automatic id feature of the, and can be rectified by checking that any manually createditems have the correct pairing ofand object. title: Simple solver for generated models
content: solver Simple solver for generated models Theory of ODE solvers False /documentation/theory/ode_solutions The theory behind how a numerical solver or integration program works is outlined in thepage. This section describes how to use the simple solvers provided to run models generated with either the C or Python profiles. C profile solver tutorials/solver code In C++ you can use the code provided in thedirectory to build your generated code into a runnable simulation. To use the package just follow the instructions below. Because the code you’ve generated needs to be built at the same time as the solver code is built, each different model requires rebuilding the solver to include the generated code. If all has gone well you should see the output similar to: _solution.txt code The parameters read from the file, along with your command line arguments are printed to the terminal for checking, and the results of the simulation written to a tab-delimited file with the extensionafter your base file name. C/C++ resources CMakeLists.txt xref download c3875bfa0c2a1f1d593bc10fb1635cbf/CMakeLists.txt resources/code/solver/index True CMakeLists.txt download False The CMake file which controls the building of the solver. Note that this is a little different from usual, as outlined below. solveGeneratedModel.cpp xref download bcee499fcda27579ee11394c8ddb8c88/solveGeneratedModel.cpp resources/code/solver/index True solveGeneratedModel.cpp download False The source file. - directorylist 1.a tutorials/solver code Assuming you’ve already generated code using the C profile, open a terminal window and navigate into thedirectory. dothis 1.b NB tutorials/solver code The next step is to build your generated code into the solver code. From inside thedirectory, use the CMake command line to point to your generated files.It’s assumed that both of the header and source files have the same base filename (eg: baseFileName.c and baseFileName.h). The general CMake command is below. dothis this Note that the fullstop in the cmake command sets both the source and binary directories to the solver directory. This is because even though your generated files are elsewhere, the solver code and CMakeLists.txt file are indirectory. nb 1.c Following the instructions in the output, next you need to build the executable by entering: dothis 1.d solve_ code baseFileName code -n code -dt code Finally you’re ready to solve your model. The executable will have been given the prefixand then your, and can be run using the command line flagsto indicate the number of steps to run, andto indicate the step size. For example: dothis c-profile-solver c\ profile\ solver Python profile solver Theory of ODE solver False /documentation/theory/ode_solutions The solver script is a very simple implementation of the Euler stepping method in Python. The theory on which it’s based can be found on thepage. Generator code Once you’ve used theto write a CellML model into Python format, you need to run it to produce the solution. The script can be run from the command line as below: resources/tutorial3_PredatorPrey_generated.py code You should see output to the terminal which echoes the settings and initial conditions, as below. An example file for running is provided for you in thefile, which can be run for 2000 steps and a step size of 0.01. Running this will give you the terminal output: _solution.txt code The output is a tab delimited file with the endingafter the input file name (note that it’s in the same directory as the running file too), which can be opened by the plotting program of your choice. Python resources solveGeneratedModel.py xref download 720f0969a3d62e612fd4909324baa756/solveGeneratedModel.py resources/code/solver/index True solveGeneratedModel.py download False The solver script. - directorylist Navigate into the “solver” directory dothis Run the solver. To do this you’ll need to enter: -m code the path to the generated file to run, relative to the solver directory; -dt code the step size for the integration variable to take; and -n code the total number of steps to take. - dothis python-profile-solver python\ profile\ solver simple-solver-for-generated-models solver simple\ solver\ for\ generated\ models solver /Users/libcellml/BuildbotWorker/Finalise_Release_Builder/howto-tested-docs/resources/code/solver/index.rst https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/ https://www.sphinx-doc.org/

content: build-from-source Build and install from source Contents 0: Gather the prerequisites id1 gather-the-prerequisites 1: Create the libCellML library id2 create-the-libcellml-library 2: Build and install the library id3 build-and-install-the-library 3: Test the installation: C++ id4 test-the-installation-c 4: Test the installation: Python id5 test-the-installation-python contents local contents contents 0: Gather the prerequisites id1 libxml2 False http://www.xmlsoft.org/ this page False https://github.com/CMLibs-Dependencies/libxml2/releases If you’re working on a Windows or Linux machine you’ll need to haveinstalled. It can be downloaded from. This is present by default on MacOS operating systems. SWIG False http://www.swig.org/ If you’d like to build the Python bindings, you’ll need to have access to. If you will only be working in C++ then you don’t need this step. gather-the-prerequisites 0:\ gather\ the\ prerequisites 1: Create the libCellML library id2 1.a Create an empty folder and navigate into it. dothis 1.b libcellml code Clone the branch from the libCellML library github repository. This will create and populate a folder called. dothis 1.c libcellml code source code build code install code Rename the clonedfolder to be, and create sibling folders calledand: dothis Your folder structure is now: Your folder structure should now look like this: create-the-libcellml-library 1:\ create\ the\ libcellml\ library 2: Build and install the library id3 2.a MyLibCellMLDirectory/build code Navigate into thedirectory to make the library: dothis -S code -B code CMake uses command line flags as well as the arguments’ positions to determine what each of your inputs means. In the example above theflag indicates the source directory, and theflag indicates the build directory. By default, if these flags are not present, CMake will take the first unflagged item as the source directory (if there are none then it uses the current directory), and the second (if there is no second then it uses the current directory) as the build directory. Thus, if called from the build directory, then these are equivalent: infospec 2.b From the same location, install the library: dothis 2.c (optional) build code If you intend to use the Python bindings, you will need to install the Python version of the local library using pip3. Again, this expects that you are still in thedirectory. dothis 2.d (optional) build code Run the tests on the library from thedirectory.
