title: A model of a sodium channel
content: sodium-channel A model of a sodium channel HH Tutorial 3 False https://libcellml.org/documentation/latest/tutorials/hh_tutorial3/index The second ion channel in Hodgkin-Huxley model controls sodium. The theory here is the basis for the the practical modelling tutorial in. Theory id3 theory Interpretation as a CellML model id4 interpretation-as-a-cellml-model Simulation and results id5 simulation-and-results Notable results id6 notable-results Next steps id7 next-steps contents local contents contents Theory id3 m m = 0 h h = 1 The Hodgkin-Huxley model’s sodium channel has two types of gate, an-gate (of which there are 3) that is initially closed () before activating and inactivating back to the closed state, and an-gate that is initially open () before activating and inactivating back to the open state. The short period when both types of gate are open allows a brief window current to pass through the channel. Therefore, \bar{g}_{Na} = \ \left\lbrack Na^{+} \right\rbrack_{i} \left\lbrack Na^{+} \right\rbrack_{o} z=1 where120 mS.cm, and with= 30mM and= 140mM, the Nernst potential for the sodium channel () is: The gating kinetics are described by: 1 sodium_channel id1 id2 where the voltage dependence of these four rate constants is determined experimentallyto be: i_{Na} = \bar{i}_{Na}m^{3}h = m^{3}{h.}\bar{g}_{Na}\left( V - E_{Na} \right) sodium_channel True False True preserve E_{Na} = \frac{RT}{zF}\ln\frac{\left\lbrack Na^{+} \right\rbrack_{o}}{\left\lbrack Na^{+} \right\rbrack_{i}} \approx 35\text{mV}. sodium_channel True False True preserve \frac{dm}{dt} = \alpha_{m}\left( 1 - m \right) - \beta_{m}.m \frac{dh}{dt} = \alpha_{h}\left( 1 - h \right) - \beta_{h}.h sodium_channel True False True preserve \alpha_{m} = \frac{- 0.1\left( V + 50 \right)} {\exp {\left( - 0.1 \left( V + 50 \right)\right)} - 1} \\[5pt] \beta_{m} = 4 \exp \left( {\frac{- \left( V + 75 \right)}{18}} \right) \\[5pt] \alpha_{h} = 0.07\exp\left( {\frac{- \left( V + 75 \right)}{20}}\right) \\[5pt] \beta_{h} = \frac{1} {\exp {\left(- 0.1 \left( V + 45 \right)\right)} + 1} sodium_channel True False True preserve theory-sodiumchannel-interpretation theory theory Interpretation as a CellML model id4 encapsulation groups public private parent child sibling Figure 13 std std-numref True encapsulation-parent-structure Figure %s Before we construct a model of the sodium channel, we first introduce some further CellML concepts that help deal with the complexity inherent in biological modelling. First we’ll look at the use ofandandinterfaces to control the visibility of information in modular CellML components. To understand encapsulation, it is useful to use terms like,and, to describe the relationships between components. This is illustrated inbelow: Defining an encapsulation structure controls which components are able to see and be seen by which others, as defined by the available interface types: sodium_channel_m_gate sodium_channel_h_gate sodium_channel We define the CellML componentsandbelow. Each of these components has its own equations (voltage-dependent gates and first-order gate kinetics) but they are both parts of one protein – the sodium channel – so it is useful to group them into onecomponent. Encapsulation structure of nested components in a parent-child-sibling structure {'*': 'images/encapsulation_parent_structure.png'} images/encapsulation_parent_structure.png Encapsulation structure of nested components in a parent-child-sibling structure. center encapsulation-parent-structure encapsulation_parent_structure {'*': 'images/sodium_channel_encap_structure.png'} images/sodium_channel_encap_structure.png m h private interface public interface The sodium channel component is the parent of two children: the-gate and the-gate components, which are therefore siblings. Aallows a parent to talk to its children and aallows siblings to talk among themselves and to their parents. left sodium-chanel-encapsulation-structure sodium-channel-encap-structure sodium_chanel_encapsulation_structure sodium_channel_encap_structure possible none code By default, no interface exists between components. The types of interface listed below are those which are; but each must be explicitly specified before it can be used. Whileis the implied default, it may be specified explicitly as well. public code Model code public code Figure 13 std std-numref True encapsulation-parent-structure Figure %s from to Ainterface is available between siblings. This is also true of top-level components (which are siblings with aparent), such as the ‘grandparent’ and ‘no relation’ components in. Ainterface is also availablea childits parent (note direction). private code from to Ainterface is availablea parentits child(ren), again noting the direction. public code private code public_and_private code public_and_private code Bothandinterfaces are available using thetype, needed where there is more than one level of nesting (for example, a grandparent-parent-child structure). Here, the parent must define ainterface type as it is both the child of the grandparent, and the parent of the child. Communication through the aunt-child, grandparent-child, and cousin-parent relationships is not possible as there is no available interface. Communication with the no-relation component is only possible with the grandparent because, as top-level components, they are siblings. - sodium-channel-encap-structure interpretation-as-a-cellml-model theory-sodiumchannel-interpretation interpretation\ as\ a\ cellml\ model theory_sodiumchannel_interpretation Simulation and results id5 simple solver False https://libcellml.org/documentation/solver HH Tutorial 3 False https://libcellml.org/documentation/latest/tutorials/hh_tutorial3/index Figure 15 std std-numref True sodium-voltage Figure %s Figure 19 std std-numref True sodium-i Figure %s The behaviour of the sodium channel was simulated using theprovided to run the code generated in. title: A model of a potassium channel
content: potassium-channel A model of a potassium channel the previous chapter on ion gates theory std std-ref True ion_gates#ion-gates HH Tutorial 2 False https://libcellml.org/documentation/latest/tutorials/hh_tutorial2/index We now deal specifically with the application of the ion channel model discussed into the Hodgkin and Huxley (HH) potassium channel. This theory is the basis for the practical modelling tutorial in. Theory id3 theory Interpretation into a CellML model id4 interpretation-into-a-cellml-model An aside: Equivalent variables id5 an-aside-equivalent-variables Simulation and results id6 simulation-and-results Next steps id7 next-steps contents local contents contents Theory id3 n \gamma = 4 Following the convention introduced by Hodgkin and Huxley, the gating variable for the potassium channel isand the number of gates in series is, therefore: \bar{g}_{K} = \ 36 \text{ mS.cm}^{-2} \left\lbrack K^{+} \right\rbrack_{i} = 90\text{ mM} \left\lbrack K^{+} \right\rbrack_{o} = 3\text{ mM} z = 1 K^{+} where, and with intra- and extra-cellular concentrationsand, respectively, the Nernst potential for the potassium channel (representing the one positive charge on) is: E_K n^{4}\bar{g}_{K} equilibrium potential charges concentration Theterm is called thesince it is the potential across the cell membrane when the channel is open but no current is flowing. This happens when the electrostatic driving force from the potential (voltage) difference between internal and external ionis exactly matched by the entropic driving force from the iondifference. The channel conductance is given by. The-gate response inshows it opening beyond its initial partially open value of0.324 at 0mV, to plateau at an almost fully open state of0.945 at the Nernst potential of -85mV, before closing again as the voltage is stepped back to 0mV. Note that the opening behaviour (set by the voltage dependence of theopening rate constant) is faster than the closing behaviour (set by the voltage dependence of theclosing rate constant). The channel conductance () is shown in. Note the initial s-shaped conductance increase caused by the effect of the four gates in serieseffect on conductance. Finally the channel currentis shown in. There is no current flow during the time when the voltage is clamped at the Nernst potential (-85mV) when the gate is opening. When the voltage is stepped back to 0mV the open gates begin to close and the conductance declines, but as there is a voltage gradient it drives an outward (positive) current flow through the partially open channel. Current can only flows when there is a non-zero conductance and a non-zero voltage gradient. This is called the ‘tail current’. \left\lbrack K^{+} \right\rbrack_{i} \left\lbrack K^{+} \right\rbrack_{o} \left\lbrack K^{+} \right\rbrack_{o} Note that the simulation above includes the Nernst equation with its dependence on the concentrations= 90mM and= 3mM. By raising the external potassium concentration to= 10mM you will then seethe Nernst potential increase from -85mV to -55mV and a negative (inward) current flowing during the period when the membrane voltage is clamped to -85mV. The cell is now in a ‘hyper-polarised’ state because the potential is less than the equilibrium potential. title: Solution methods for sets of Ordinary Differential Equations
content: ode-solutions Solution methods for sets of Ordinary Differential Equations toctree-wrapper Generator code Differential equations provide the governing mathematics for most of the simulations used in computational biology and engineering. This document is a very simplified explanation for how the output files from the libCellmlfunctionality can be coupled with a numerical integrator in order to solve generated model’s system of equations. The basic premise of differential equations is that we know something about a derivative quantity (like speed) which we need to integrate to find the variable we care about (like distance). Because most numerical integrators can handle only one order of differentiation, in situations involving higher orders (like acceleration) or more than one variable of influence or interest (like drag) we need to use a set of connected equations instead of one alone. Some examples: For each variable we need to know: \frac{dy}{dt}=f(y,t) A simple first order system,representing the effects of speed-dependent drag forces on the motion of an object; \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} = f(\frac {dy}{dt}, y, t) A higher-order system,representing a spring-mass-damper system like that in shock absorbers; and \frac{dy_1}{dt} = f(y_1, y_2, t) A multi-variable system,representing population dynamics between predator and prey species over time. - gradient function evaluation How to evaluate the variable’s first derivative as the solution progresses. This is known as thestep, and includes anything and everything - including other unknown variables, constants etc - which affect the gradient of this variable. An initial condition for the variable so we have somewhere to start from. If this value is dependent on other variable values, it must nonetheless be able to be determined at the time of submitting the solver. How large a step to take through the independent variable space (like time). This is often made consistent between all variables so that their solutions progress together, though adaptive step sizing methods (in which the step size adjusts itself during the solution process) and mixed methods (in which different steps are used for different variables) are possible. In the examples here we will use a constant step-size for all variables and all steps. - Modelling situation: Swimming with sharks Generator code The remainder of this document will use the following modelling situation to explain theoutputs. Imagine a tank filled with sharks and fishes; predators and prey. The population of fish can only grow when they are not being constantly eaten by sharks, and the rate at which is grows will depend on how many fish are available for breeding. At the same time, the population of sharks will depend on how much food is available in the fish population. In maths this relationship can be written: (a, b, c, d)=(1.2, -0.6, -0.8, 0.3) y_s(t=0)=2.0 y_f(t=0)=1.0 where the constantsand we’ll use the initial condtions ofand. \frac{dy_s}{dt} =f(sharks, fishes, time) = a y_s + b y_s y_f \frac{dy_f}{dt} =f(sharks, fishes, time) = c y_f + d y_s y_f ode_solutions True False True preserve Interpretation in code: MathML, generated C, generated Python Generator code Tutorial 3 False https://libcellml.org/documentation/latest/tutorials/tutorial3/index Theinterprets your CellML model into a structure which can easily be passed to a numerical integrator. Consider the file created by completingto model a coupled system of first-order ODEs. The governing equations - that is, gradient of each variable as a function of all the others - were specified in the MathML block within the CellML as: d d=a+b+c+0.5 For the sake of illustrating the different variable types, we’ll also define the (otherwise) constantusing the simple equation: interpretation-in-code-mathml-generated-c-generated-python interpretation\ in\ code:\ mathml,\ generated\ c,\ generated\ python modelling-situation-swimming-with-sharks modelling\ situation:\ swimming\ with\ sharks Classification of variables Generator code Variable code Component code Theclassifies all theitems within eachas: implementationCode code Generator code We can see this results of this classification process in the generated code returned by a call to thefunction of the. Variables : These do not require integration, but come in three types: CONSTANT code x = 3 variables do not need any kind of calculation, and is initialised directly using a constant value (for example,); COMPUTED_CONSTANT code x = y+5 variables only need calculation in order to set their initial (and thereafter constant) value (for example,); and ALGEBRAIC code x = 3yz y z variables are computed based on the values of other variables (for example,whereand/orare not constant). - Variables of integration <bvar> code <diff> code : Also called “base variables”, “free variables”, or “VOI”, these are specified by thechild of theoperator. VOI must not be initialised. States <ci> code <diff> code : These are those variables which need integration by a solver. They are theoperand of theoperator. - C++ panel-0-Qysr true sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-0-Qysr Qysr tab 0 Python panel-0-UHl0aG9u false sphinx-tabs-tab code-tab group-tab tab-0-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tab -1 Tabbed content closeable tablist tab-0-Qysr sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab panel-0-Qysr Qysr tabpanel 0 tab-0-UHl0aG9u sphinx-tabs-panel code-tab group-tab true panel-0-UHl0aG9u UHl0aG9u tabpanel 0 sphinx-tabs tab-element classification-of-variables classification\ of\ variables Defining the initial values Variables code setInitialValue code <bvar></bvar> code Generator code Allitems must either be initialised using thefunction, or specified within the MathML as a variable of integration (VOI) using thetags. Errors will be returned by thewhere variables are either: The initial conditions for all non-VOI variables are specified in a function, as opposed to the dictonary syntax used for the information items above. This function can be called by the solver whenever the solution’s initial conditions need to be reset. are not a VOI and are missing an initial value, or are a VOI and have been initalised. - defining-the-initial-values defining\ the\ initial\ values Specification of states and rates Variable code Generator code rates code state Once ahas been identified as avariable, it is paired by theby its corresponding entry in thearray, which represents its gradient function. states code computeRates code compute_rates code Because the gradients of each of the integrated variables orcould include dependency on time or any variable’s value, the values of each gradient function array must be updated throughout the solution process. This is done by calling the(in C) or(in Python) function to recalculate the gradient values for each state variable. solving-the-model Solving the model Euler’s method False https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_method gradient function evaluation A simple numerical integration method likeinvolves stepping from the variable’s initial value, along the gradient (as evaluated by the), to a new value. This new value is used in turn to update all of the other gradient functions for other variables, and the process is repeated for all variables and all time points within the solution time interval. More complicated stepping procedures involve the combination of many points at which to evaluate the gradient function as well as relaxation and hybrid techniques. In this example we will use Euler’s method as being the simplest possible. Euler’s method updates each variable according to: f(t_k, x_k,...) gradient functions where the gradients of each variable are given by evaluating the current value of the appropriate gradient function,. It is the evaluation of thesewhich defines the nature of the physical situation represented by the model. Simple implementations are provided which will take the generated files, from both the C and Python generator profiles, and solve the system of equations. Solver tutorial False https://libcellml.org/documentation/solver Simple solver routines have been provided for you for both the C and Python profiles. Please see thefor details. Gate status for a single gate, and current through four gates {'*': 'images/tut5.png'} images/tut5.png \gamma=4 Dynamics of opening status for a single gate, and the resulting current forgates in series. center ion-gate-status ion_gate_status simulation-and-results simulation\ and\ results Next steps id19 \alpha_{y} \beta_{y} y < 1 \left( y_{\infty} \right)^{\gamma}{.\overset{\overline{}}{g}}_{Y} y_{\infty} = \frac{\alpha_{y}}{\alpha_{y} + \beta_{y}} \tau = \frac{1}{\alpha_{y} + \beta_{y}} potassium std std-ref True potassium_channel#potassium-channel sodium ion channels std std-ref True sodium_channel#sodium-channel The model of a gated ion channel presented here is used in the next two sections for the neural potassium and sodium channels. The gates create the transience of the channel’s conductance through the voltage dependence of the gating rate constantsand. This means that the channel conductance (including the open channel conductance) is voltage dependent. For a partially open channel (), the steady state conductance is, where. The gating time constantsare therefore also voltage dependent. Both of these voltage dependent factors of ion channel gating are important in explaining channel properties, as is described in the next sections for the neuraland. title: Modelling theory and background

title: The Hodgkin-Huxley model of nerve action potential
content: hodgkin-huxley-model The Hodgkin-Huxley model of nerve action potential 1 hodgkin_huxley_model id1 id4 “their discoveries concerning the ionic mechanisms involved in excitation and inhibition in the peripheral and central portions of the nerve cell membrane” Here we describe the first (and most famous) model of nerve fibre electrophysiology based on the membrane ion channels that we have discussed in the last two sections. This is the work by Alan Hodgkin and Andrew Huxley in 1952that won them (together with John Eccles) the 1963 Noble prize in Physiology or Medicine for. Theory: The cable equation id7 theory-the-cable-equation Theory: Action potentials id8 theory-action-potentials Interpretation as a CellML model id9 interpretation-as-a-cellml-model Simulation and results id10 simulation-and-results contents local contents contents Theory: The cable equation id7 cable equation 1 hodgkin_huxley_model id2 id5 Thewas developed in 1890to predict the degradation of an electrical signal passing along the transatlantic cable. It is derived as follows: Figure 20 std std-numref True leaky-cable-current-flow Figure %s i_a A If the voltage is raised at the left hand end of the cable (shown by the deep red in), an axial current(in) will flow. This current depends on the voltage gradient according to Ohm’s Law, such that: \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} V/m r_a \Omega/m whereis the voltage gradient along the cable (in), andis the resistance (in). i_m A/m If the cable membrane leaks a current of() per unit length, then conservation of current gives: i_a and, substituting forwe get: i_m C_m \mu F/cm^2 C_m\frac{\partial V}{\partial t} i_{leak} There are two sources of membrane leakage current,. First, the capacitance associated with the membrane,(approximately 1) results in a current of, and secondly the holes or channels in the membrane give. Incorporating these into the equation above gives: cable equation r_a Rearranging gives the(for constant): current density \mu A/cm^2 where all terms represent(current per membrane area) and have units of. Is one side in/out the cell? center neuron-current-flow neuron_current_flow 600px Current-voltage trajectory {'*': 'images/current_voltage_trajectory.png'} images/current_voltage_trajectory.png Current-voltage trajectory during an action potential. center current-voltage-during-action-potential current_voltage_during_action_potential CellML schematic cell membrane model {'*': 'images/hodgkin_1952.png'} images/hodgkin_1952.png + + Na K L A schematic cell diagram describing the current flows across the cell bi-lipid membrane that are captured in the Hodgkin-Huxley model. The membrane ion channels are a sodium (Na) channel, a potassium (K) channel, and a leakage (L) channel (for chloride and other ions) through which the currents I, Iand Iflow, respectively. center hodgkin-huxley-schematic hodgkin_huxley_schematic 500px inward outward i_{Na} i_K i_L = g_L\left( V - E_L \right) Figure 21 std std-numref True neuron-current-flow Figure %s TODO The cable equation above can be used to model the propagation of an action potential along a neuron or any other excitable cell. The leak current is associated primarily with the inward movement of sodium ions through the membrane’s sodium channel, giving themembrane current, and the outward movement of potassium ions through a membrane potassium channel, giving thecurrent(see). A further small leak currentassociated with chloride and other ions is also included.Need to define E_L and g_L ?? How is i_L related to i_leak above?? V Na^+ K^+ Figure 22 std std-numref True current-voltage-during-action-potential Figure %s When the membrane potentialrises due to axial current flow, the sodium () channels open and the potassium () channels close, such that the membrane potential moves towards the Nernst potential for sodium. The subsequent decline of the Na channel conductance and the increasing K channel conductance as the voltage drops rapidly repolarises the membrane to its resting potential of -85mV (see). 1 hodgkin_huxley_model id3 id6 If we assume that the whole cell is clamped with an axially-uniform potential then we can neglectthe term in the equation above representing the rate of change of axial current along the cable: V and so obtain the membrane potentialby integrating the first order ODE: TODO How are the i_L and I_L in the figure related? Consistent labelling needed? - \frac{1}{r_a}\frac{\partial^{2}V}{\partial x^2} \approx 0 hodgkin_huxley_model True False True preserve \frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{- \left( i_{Na} + \ i_K + i_L \right)}{C_m} hodgkin_huxley_model True False True preserve theory-action-potentials theory:\ action\ potentials Interpretation as a CellML model id9 encapsulation previous section on the sodium channel std std-ref True sodium_channel#sodium-channel Figure 24 std std-numref True cellml-of-hh-model Figure %s We discussed the idea and implementation ofin the, and here it is no different. We would like to create a model with the encapsulation structure shown in. imports HH Tutorial 2 Creating a model which uses imports HH Tutorial 2 Creating a model which uses imports https://libcellml.org/documentation/latest/tutorials/hh_tutorial2/index As with other aspects of libCellML, there are several options for the model construction process. Since we already have potassium and sodium channel models available, it would make sense to be able to reuse these here. This functionality requires; their use is demonstrated in. HH Tutorial 1 Creating a model using the API HH Tutorial 1 Creating a model using the API https://libcellml.org/documentation/latest/tutorials/hh_tutorial1/index HH Tutorial 3 Debugging a model HH Tutorial 3 Debugging a model https://libcellml.org/documentation/latest/tutorials/hh_tutorial3/index Importing allows all or part of a model to be used in-situ, without needing to manually parse its CellML file and instantiate it as an additional model (as has been the procedure inand). In this instance, the models described earlier representing aand a, as well as one to represent the leakage concept introduced above can be combined to make the full Hodgkin-Huxley model.
